Play details
The sparagvs garden. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1640. Date first performed: 1635.
THE SPARAGVS Garden: A COMEDIE. Acted in the yeare 1635. by the then Company of Revels, at Salisbury Court.
Front matter Hic totus volo rideat Libellus. Mart.
To the Right Honourable WILLIAM Earle of New-Castle, &c. Governour to the Prince his Highnesse.
My LORD! Your favourable Construction of my poore Labours commanded my Service to your Honour, and, in that, betray'd your worth to this Dedication: I am not ignorant how farre unworthy my best endeavours are of your least allowacne; yet let your Lordship be pleased to know you, in this, share but the inconveniences of the most renowned Princes as you partake of their glories: And I doubt not, but it will more divulge your noble Disposition
to the World, when it is knowne you can freely pardon an Officious trespasse against your Goodnes. Cæsar had never bin commended for his Clemency, had there not occasion beene offered, wherein hee might shew, how willingly hee could forgive: I shall thanke my Fortune, if this weake presentation of mine shall any way encrease the Glory of your Name among Good Men, which is the chiefest ayme and onely study of Your Honours devoted servant, Richard Brome .
To his deserving friend Mr. Richard Brome on his Sparagus Garden, a Comedy. [By C. G.]
What ever walke I in your Garden use, Breeds my delight, and makes me love thy Muse For the designment; sith I cannot spie A prospect, which doth more envite mine eye: I'me in a maze, and know not how to find A freedome that will more delight my mind, Then this imprisonment within thy Bower, Where houres seeme minutes, and each day an hower: Nor, were my stay perpetuall, could I grieve, Where such rare fruits mine appetite relieve. The envious Criticke would recant to see How much opprest is every virgin tree. With her owne burthen: Leekes, and Akornes here Are food for Critickes; but the choycer cheere, For those, can rellish Delicates I might In praysing of thy worth, be infinite: But thou art modest and disdain'st to heare A tedious, glorious, needlesse Character Of thee and of thy Muse: Yet I could say, (Give me but leave) it is no common Play. Within thy plot of ground, no Weed doth spring, To hurt the growth of any Vnderling: Nor is thy Laborinth confus'd, but wee In that disorder, may proportion see: Thy Hearbs are physicall, and do more good In purging Humors, then some's letting blood. C. G.
To the Author on his Sparagus Garden . [By R. W.] Friend, What dost meane, that thus thou dost entice Thy Lovers, thus to walke in Paradice? Most skilfull Artist! that so well dost know To plant, for profit, as for out-ward show; For on thy Sparagus are throughly pleased Our intellects; others scarce hunger eased. The wisest of the Age shall hither come, And thinke their time well spent as was their summe. The Sqint-ey'd Criticke that such care do's take, To looke for that he loatheth to partake: Now crossing his warp'd Nature shall be kind, And vexing grieve 'cause he no fault can find. The ignorant of the times that do delight, Not in a Play, but how to wast day-light, Shall resort hither, 'till that you descry, With pleasure, smiling April in each eye. Alcinou's garden, which each day did spring, And her lov'd fruit unto perfection bring, Ought not compare with this: Here Men did grow: Such care thy Arte and Labour did bestow For man's wel-being, and a-new create, And poyse them up above a needy Fate. Is it not pitty ought should hurt this Spring? (A Serpent in a Garden's no new thing) Yet wisely hath thy goodnesse tooke a care, He should sting none, but who censorious are. R. W.
The Prologue to the Play.
He, that his wonted modesty retaynes, And never set a price upon his Braines Above your Judgments; nor did ever strive By Arrogance or Ambition to atchieve More prayse unto himselfe, or more applause Vnto his Scenes, then such, as know the Lawes Of Comedy do give; He only those Now prayes may scan his Verse, and weigh his Prose: Yet thus far he thinks meet to let you know Before you see't, the Subject is so low, That to expect high Language, or much Cost, Were a sure way, now, to make all be lost. Pray looke for none: He'le promise such hereafter, To take your graver judgments, now your laughter Is all he aymes to moove. I had more to say --- The Title, too, may prejudice the Play. It sayes the Sparagus Garden; if you looke To feast on that, the Title spoiles the Booke. We have yet a tast of it, which he doth lay I'th midst o'th journey, like a Bait by th'way: Now see with Candor: As our Poet's free, Pray let be so your Ingenuity.
The Persons in the Comedy. 1 Gilbert young Gentleman and friend [to Walter.] Walter young Gentleman and friend [to Gilbert.] Touch-wood Old adversarie [of Striker], and Iustice. Striker Old adversarie [of Touch-wood], and Iustice. Samuel, Sonne to Touch-wood. Mony-lacks, a needy Knight, that lives by shifts. Brittleware Confederate with Mony-lacks. Springe Confederate with Mony-lacks. Tim. Hoyden, the new made Gentleman. Coulter, his Man. Thomas Hoyden, Tim. Hoydens brother. Sir Arnold Cautious, a stale Batchelour, and a rediculous Lover of women. A Gardiner. Trampler, a Lawyer. Curat. Three Courtiers. Annabel, Daughter to Mony-lacks, and Grand-childe to Striker. Friswood, her nurse: and House-keeper to Striker. Rebecca, wife to Brittle-ware. Martha, the Gardiners wife. Three Ladies.

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Annabel Brittleware Sir Arnold Cautious Coulter Rebecca Friswood Gilbert Tim Hoyden Thomas Hoyden Gardiner Trampler Martha Money-lacks Springe Curate Prologue Gentleman Striker Samuel Touchwood Boy 1Courtier Walter Combined speech 1 Lady 2Courtier 2Lady Servant Woman/Wife Litter Man

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: I fear we shall do no good upon him.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: We shall nevertheless discharge the office of friends in our endeavour. I mean to put it home to him.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: And so will I.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: But be sure you lie at a close ward the while; for he is a most subtle and dangerous Fencer to deal withal.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: I understand you.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: He has not his name for nothing; old Touchwood! he is all fire if he be incensed; but so soft and gentle that you may wind him about your finger, or carry him in your bosom if you handle him rightly: but still be wary, for the least spark kindles him. He comes.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: With me gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Only a few neighbourly and friendly words sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: O you are most friendly welcome good Master. Gilbert Goldwier, and Master. Walter Chamlet I take ye to be.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: The same sir at your service.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Your fathers both were my good neighbours indeed; worthy and well reputed members of the City while they lived: but that may be read upon the Hospital walls, and gates; it is enough for me to say they loved me: Sanson Touchwood! and I were a wretch if I should not honour their memory in their happy succession: Again gentlemen you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Yet you may be pleased sir to remember, though our fathers were both loving friends to you, yet they were sometimes at odds one with another.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: True, true, ever at odds: They were the common talk of the town for a pair of wranglers; still at strife for one trifle or other: they were at law loggerheads together, in one match that held them tugging one the other by the purse strings a matter of nine years, and all for a matter of nothing. They coursed one another from Court to Court, and through every Court Temporal and Spiritual; and held one an other play till they lost a thousand pound a man to the Lawyers, and till it was very sufficiently adjudged that your father was one fool, and your father was another fool. And so again gentlemen you are welcome: now your business.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: You may now be pleased sir to remember that our fathers grew friends at last.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Heaven forbid else.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And note the cause, the ground of their reconciliation, which was upon the love, betwixt me and this gentleman's sister. My fathers Son married his fathers Daughter, and out two fathers grew friends, and wise men again.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: To the point good gentlemen, yet you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Troth sir the point is this: You know (and the town has taken sufficient notice of it) that there has been a long contention betwixt you and old Master Striker your neighbour ---

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p:
And the cause or ground of your quarrel (for aught anybody
knows but yourselves) may be as trivial, as that which was derided in our fathers.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Are you there with me?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And great hopes there are, and wagers laid by your friends on both sides, that you two will be friends.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I will hold you an hundred pounds on that.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Nay, more, that Master. Striker will be willing to give his Grandchild to your Son, so you will give your consent.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And your coming is to persuade that, is it not? if it be so, speak; deal plainly with me gentlemen, whilst yet you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: In sooth it is so, we come to negotiate the match for your son, and your friendship with old Master. Striker.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: You are not welcome.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: But when you weigh the reasons, and consider the perfect love of the young pair, and how the world will praise your reconciliation, and bless the providence, that made their loves the means to work their parents charity.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Again you are not welcome.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Yourself but now commended the atonement Of our two fathers, wrought by the same means: I mean my marriage with his sister here Against as great an opposition.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: But our fathers loved their children.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Your fathers were a couple of doting fools, and you a pair of saucy knaves; now you are not welcome: and more than so, get you out of my doors.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Will you sir, by your wilfulness, cast away your son?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: My son? no son of mine, I have cast him off already for casting an eye upon the daughter of mine enemy: let him go, let him pack; let him perish: he comes not within these doors, and you, that are his fine spoken spokesmen, get you off of my ground I charge you.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: We are gone sir: only but wishing you Master. Touchwood to remember that your son is your son.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p:
Indefinitely not sir, until he does not only renounce all interest in the love of that baggage; but do some extraordinary mischief in that family to right me for the trespass he has
done; and so win my good opinion, till which be done a daily curse of mine he shall not miss; and so you may inform him.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: What an uncharitable wretch is this?

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: The touchiest piece of Touchwood that ever I met withal.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I feared we should inflame him.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: All the comfort is, his son may yet outlive him.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: But the danger is, his father may disinherit him

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: He cannot be so devilish; here comes his son, a gentleman of so sweet a disposition, and so contrary to his crabbed Sire, that a man who never heard of his mothers virtue might wonder who got him for him.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Not at all I assure you, Sam is his fathers own son: for the old man you see, is gentle enough, till he be incensed; and the son being moved, is as fiery as the father.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: But he is very seldom and slowly moved; his father often and on the sudden.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I prithee wouldst thou have green wood take fire as soon as that which is old and sere?

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: He is deep in thought.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Over head and ears in his Mistress. contemplation.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: To disobey a father, is a crime In any son unpardonable. Is this rule So general that it can bear no exception? Or is a fathers power so illimitable, As to command his sons affections? And so control the Conqueror of all men Even Love himself? no: he, that enterprises So great a work, forgets he is a man; And must in that forget he is a father, And so if he forgo his nature, I By the same Law may leave my Piety. But stay, I would not lose myself in following This wild conceit

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: How now Sam, whither away?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I was but casting how to find the way Unto myself. Can you direct me gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: Yes, yes; your father has told us the way.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Have you had conference with him? have ye? speak.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Marry sir have we, and I think to purpose.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Have you won aught upon him to my advantage?

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: As much as may restore you to acquaintance With him again, can you but make good use on it.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Pray do not trifle with me; tell me briefly.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Briefly he says you must not dare to see him; Nor hope to receive blessing to the value Of a new three pence, till you disclaim your love In your fair Annabell; and not only so, But you must do some villainous mischievous act To vex his adversary, her Grandfather; Or walk beneath his curse in banishment.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A most uncharitable and unnatural sentence.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: But think withal it is your father, that Makes this decree; obey him in the execution: He has a great Estate, you are his only son: Do not lose him, your fortune, and yourself For a frail piece of beauty: shake her off; And do some notable thing against her house, To please your father

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: The Devil speaks it in thee, And with this spell I must Conjure him out.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: O friend you are too violent.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: He is too desperate, To urge me to an act of such injustice. Can her fair love, to whom my faith is given, Be answered with so loud an injury? Or can my faith so broken yield a sound Less terrible than thunder, to affright All love and constancy out of the breast Of every Virgin that shall hear the breach Of my firm faith?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Be not so passionate.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p:
I have no further power to do an outrage
Against that Family to whom my heart Is linked, than to rip out this troubled heart The only ominous cause, indeed, of all. My over passionate fathers cruelty; and that (If I must needs do an injurious Office) Alone, shall be my act to calm his fury.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Prithee blow over this passion; thou wert wont To affect wit, and canst not be a Lover Truly without it. Love is wit itself, And through a thousand lets will find a way To his desired end.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: The Ballet taught you that.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Well said, Love will find out the way: I see thou art coming to thyself again, Can there no shift, no witty slight be found (That have been common in all times and ages) To blind the eyes of a weak sighted father, And reconcile these dangerous differences But by bloodshedding, or outrageous deeds, To make the feud the greater? recollect Thyself good Sam; my house, my purse, my counsel Shall all be thine, and Wat shall be thy friend.

sp.speaker: Walt.
sp.p: Let me entreat your friendship.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: And me your pardon.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: So, so, all friends; let us home and there consult To lay the tempest of thy fathers fury; Which cannot long be dangerous, it is but like A storm in April, spent in swift extremes, When straight the Sun shoots forth his cheerful beams.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You will not assault me in mine own house? I hope you will not; nor urge me beyond my patience with your borroughing attempts! good sir Hugh Mony-lacks I hope you will not.

sp.speaker: Mon.
Stri.
sp.p: Private conference! a new coined word for borrowing of money; I tell you, your very face, your countenance (though it be glossed with Knighthood) looks so borrowingly, that the best words you give me are as dreadful as Stand and deliver, and there I think I was with ye. I am plain with ye sir, old Will Striker I.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: My father Striker, I am bold to call you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Your father! no, I desire no such near acquaintance with you, good sir Hugh Mony-lacks: you are a Knight and a noble gentleman, I am but an Esquire and out of debt; and there I think I was with ye again

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I shall be with you anon, when you have talked yourself out of breath.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: It is true, I had the honour to be your Worships father in law when time was, that your Knighthood married and Ladyfied a poor daughter of mine: but yet she had five thousand pounds in her purse if you please to remember it; and as I remember you had then fourteen hundred a year: But where is it now? and where is my daughter now? poor abused Innocent; your righteousness abroad, and her long night watches at home shortened her days, and cast her into her grave --- And it was not long before all your estate was buried too; and there I was with ye again I take it: but that could not fetch her again.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: No sir, I wish my life might have excused Hers, far more precious: never had a man A juster cause to mourn.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Nor mourned more justly, it is your only wearing; you have just none other: nor have had means to purchase better any time these seven years as I take it. By which means you have got the name of the mourning Knight; and there I am sure I was with ye.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Sir, if you will not be pleased to hear my desires to you, let me depart without your derision.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p:
Even when you please, and whither you please good sir Hugh Mony-lacks: my house shall be no enchanted Castle to detain your Knight errandship from your adventures. I hope
your errand hither was but for your dinner; and so far forth (and especially at your going forth) you are welcome. Your daughter I do keep, and will for her poor mothers sake; (that was my daughter) peace be with her --- she shall be no more a trouble to you; nor be your child any longer: I have made her mine; I will adopt her into mine own name, and make her a Striker; she shall be no more a Mony-lacks, and if she please me well in matching with a husband, I know what I will do for her.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Do you thank me sir, I assure you you need not; for I mean so to order her estate, and bind it up in that trust that you shall never finger a farthing on it: am I with ye sir?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I cannot choose but thank you though in behalf of my child.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Call her your child again, or let me but hear that you suffer her to ask you a bare blessing, I will send her after you upon adventures sir Knight: and who shall give a portion with her then? or what can she hope from a father that groans under the weight of a Knighthood for want of means to support it?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I shall find means to live without your trouble hereafter.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You may, you may; you have a wit sir Hugh, and a projective one; what, have you some new project a foot now, to outgo that of the Hand-barrows? what call you them the Sedams? O cry you mercy, cry you mercy; I heard you had put in for a share at the Asparagus Garden: or that at least you have a Pension thence; to be their Gather guest and bring them custom, and that you play the fly of the new Inn there; and sip with all companies: am I with ye there sir?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You may be when you please sir; I can command the best entertainment there for your money.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: In good time sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
In the meantime sir, I had no mind to beg nor borrow of you, and though you will not, give me leave to call you father, nor my daughter my daughter, yet I thought it might become my care to advertise you (that have taken the care of her from me) of a danger that will much afflict you, if it be not
carefully prevented.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: How is this?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You have an adversary ---

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: But one that I know, the rascal my neighbour Touchwood.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: There I am with ye sir, I am informed that his only son is an earnest Suitor to your Daughter: (I must not call her mine)

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: That there is a deep secret love betwixt them; and that they have had many private meetings: and a stolen match very likely to be made if you prevent it not.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Can this be true?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Give me but a piece from you, and if by due examination you find it not so, I will never see your face again till you send for me.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: To be rid of you take it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I am gone sir, and yet I think I am with ye.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Is the Devil become a match broker? what, who within there: what? Annabell? what Friswood?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Here sir, I am here forsooth.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Are you so forsooth? but where is your Mistress forsooth?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Listening is good sometimes; I heard their talk, and am glad on it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Where is your Mistress. I say?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: My Mistress. Annabell, forsooth, my young Mistress?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What other Mistress hast thou but the Devils Dam herself, your old Mistress.? and her I ask not for; good Mistress. Flibber de' Jibb with the French fly flap of your coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Is the old man mad trow?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I ask for Annabell.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Bless me! how do you look?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Where is Annabell I say? fetch her me quickly, least I bast her out of your old Whet-leather hide.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
How youthful you are grown? she is not far to fetch sir; you know you commanded her to her chamber, and not to
appear in sight, till her debauched father was gone out of the house.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: And is not he gone now forsooth? why call you her not?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I warrant he has told you some tale on her. That lewd Knight, now he has undone himself by his unthrifty practises, begins to practise the undoing of his daughter too! is it not so forsooth? has he not put some wickedness into your head to set you against her?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I never knew thee a Witch till now.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; I warrant he told you that your adversary Touchwoods son, and my Mistress Annabell are in love league together.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Marry did he; and I will know the truth.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Darest thou laugh at me?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: No, no; but I laugh at the poor Knights officiousness, in hope of some great reward for the gullery that I put upon him: ha, ha, ha. Good sir a little patience, and I will tell! you. Ha, ha, ha --- it was I that devised it for a lie, and told it him in hope that his telling of it to you, would provoke you to beat him out of the house; for reporting a thing that had no probability or resemblance of a truth in it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Is it but so?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Sir I have been your creature this thirty years, down lying and uprising; (as you know) and you should believe me, you had me in my old Mistresses dayes ---

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Aye, thou wast a handsome young wench then; now thou art old.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Yet not so wondrous old as to be sung in a Ballet for it, or to have been able ere Adam wore beard to have crept into Eves bad, as I did into my Mistresses. (Heaven pardon you, as I do with all my heart.)

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What in thy fooleries now?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Nor so old neither but you are content to make a sorry shift with me still; as your abilities will serve you ---

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Come, come; thou art not old.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
Nay that is not it that troubles me: but that I, that served you before your daughter was born; I mean your daughter that
was mother to this daughter which now you have made your daughter; that I that saw the birth, the marriage, and the death of your daughter; and have had the governance of this her daughter ever since, till now she is marriageable; and have all this while been as pliant as a twig about you, and as true as the sheath to your steel as we say, that I should now be mistrusted to connive at an ill match for her, for whom my chiefest care has been from the Cradle? there is the unkindness.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Enough, enough; Fid. I believe there is no such matter.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I thought you had known me ---

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I do, I do; I prithee good Fid be quiet, it was a witty trick of thee to mock the poor Knight withal: but a pox on him, he cost me a piece for his news; there is another for thee: but the best is he hath tied himself by it, never to trouble me more; I have that into my bargain.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: And you would tie me so too; would you?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Not so Fid, not so: but look to my Girl, and thus far mark me. If ever I find that young Touchwood, the son of that miscreant, whose hatred I would not lose for all the good neighbourhood in the Parish; if ever I say, he and your charge do but look upon one another, I will turn her and you both out of doors: there I will be with ye, look to it.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Agreed sir; agreed.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Look to it I say, I must abroad, my anger is not over yet: I would I could meet my adversary to scold it out; I shall be sick else.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: It was well I overheard them, my young lovers had been spoiled else: had not I crossed the old angry man's purpose before he had met with the young timorous Virgin, she had confessed all; and and all had been dashed now.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: How now Fris. is my Grandfather gone out of door?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: If he were as safe out of the world, it were well for you.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Nay say not so good Fris.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
Your unlucky father has destroyed all your hopes in Master.
Sam Touchwood; in discovering your loves (what Devil soever gave him the intelligence) and you must resolve never to see your sweet Sam again.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I must resolve to die first: O.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Odds pity! how now! why Mistress. why Annabell, why Mistress. Annabell; look up, look up I say, and you shall have him spite of your Grandfather and all his works: what do you think I am an Infidel, to take Master. Samuels forty pieces? and a Ronlet of old Muscadine for nothing? come be well, and indeed you shall have him.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: O Sam, sweet Sam ---

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: These lovesick maids seldom call upon other Saints than their sweethearts; look up I say, your sweet Sam is coming.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Ha, where? where is he, why do you abuse me?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I say he will come presently; look up I say, forgive me! he comes indeed: my Master. thought I was a witch, and I now suspect myself for one. O Master Samuel, how came you hither? here he is Mistress. what mean you to come now to undo her and yourself too? yet she had died and you had not come as you did. Why do you not look upon him and be well? get you gone, we are all undone if my Master. come back and find you: speak to her quickly, then kiss her and part, you will be parted for ever else.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: How fares my love?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Better than when I was in earthly being, This bosom is a heaven to me; through death I am arrived at bliss, most happily To be so well revived thou madest me die.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I made you not die, as you will die, if you stand prattling till my Master. return and take you: for Master. Samuel, I must tell you Master. Samuel, he knows all Master. Samuel.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p:
My father knows as much, and that is the cause Of my adventuring hither to instruct you In a strange practice; here it is in writing,
It is such a secret that I durst not trust My tongue with the conveyance of it; nor have I The confidence to hear it read: take it, And in my absence join your best advises, To give it life and action; it is rule Which (though both hard and grievous to pursue) Is all that can our hopes in love renew.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: What horrible thing must we do trow? pray let me see the paper, I hope there is no pistoling nor poisoning in it: though my old Striker come short of the man he was to be with me, I would be loath to shorten his days with the danger of my neck; or making a Bonfire in Smithfield: pray let me see the paper.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Not until my departure gentle Friswood.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Is there such horror in it, that you dare not stand the opening of the paper?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Consider sweet our love is Fever sick, Even desperately to death; And nothing but a desperate remedy Is left us: for our bodily health, what sour Unsavoury loathsome medicines we will take But to remove an Ague? What sharpe incisions, searings, and cruel Corrosives Are daily suffered, and what limbs dissevered To keep a Gangrene from the vital parts, That a dismembered body yet may live! We in like case must to preserve our love, (If we dare say we love) adventure life, Fame, Honour, which are all but Loves attendants To maintain it.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I understand you, sweet, And do before I read your strong injunction, Resolve to give it faithful execution What ever it be. I have got courage now, And (with a constant boldness let me tell you) You dare not lay that on me I will not bear: And Love, predominant over all other passions, Shall bear me out in it.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: O you have made me happy.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: As I live my Master --- Kiss and away; whip quickly through the Garden --- Run you up to your Chamber; I will see you out myself.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Thus let us breath that till we meet again.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Whoop what do ye mean?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: We leave for truce at raising of the siege, Our interchanged hearts each others pledge.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Go fools, this sets you both but more on edge.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Farewell,

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Sweet wife content thyself.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Yes content myself! shall I so? with what, you Iohn Bopeepe? you must be my husband, and I must content myself, must I? no sir, it is you that must content me, or it is your heart must smart for it.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: If you could be content with all that I have, or all that I can do, and expect no further, I then might hope to pacify you.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: All has not done it yet you see, nor have you yet found out the way. Five years practice one would think were sufficient, so long you have had me; and too long it Is unless I had got a better name by it, to be accounted barren --- O me.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Now it is out; sons what would you have me do? where is the defect think you? is it not probable that you may be defective as well as I?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: That I may be defective! I defy thee, Lubber; I defy thee and all that say so, thou fribbling fumbler thou; I would some honest sufficient man might be Judge betwixt us whether I be defective.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How now, always wrangling?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Defective quoth a ---

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: What is the matter Landlord?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Do I look like a thing defective?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Land-Lady ---

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: O fearful!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Mistress. Brittle-ware what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Reb.
Brit.
sp.p: You will not be impudent?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Good: Master. Brittle-ware what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: The matter is sir she will be content with nothing.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: The best wife in the world! and if you cannot afford her that to content her, you are a most hardhearted husband.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: What nothing? would you wish him to afford me nothing to content me? I must have something to content me; and something he must find me, or I will make him look out for it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Come, come, I know the quarrel; and I know you will never get a child by falling out.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Nor any way else so long as he is such a jealous beast as he is.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: O you must leave your jealousy Master. Brittleware; that is a main hindrance

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I am not jealous I.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Not, and stare like a mad Ox upon every man that looks upon me?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Fie upon him, is he such a beast, to be jealous of his own wife? if every man were so, it would spoil the getting of some children in a year.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: And denies me all things that I have a mind to.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: The best is the loss of your longings will not hurt you; unless you were with child.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p:
I must have my longings first; I am not every woman I,
I must have my longings before I can be with child I.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: You must not long for every strange thing you see or hear of then.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: As true as I live he fribbles with me sir Hugh, I do but now long for two or three idle things scarce worth the speaking of; and do you think he will grant me one of them?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: What may they be? he shall grant them.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: One of my longings is to have a couple of lusty able bodied men, to take me up, one before and another behind, as the new fashion is, and carry me in a Man-litter into the great bad at Ware.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: There is one, and will you deny her this to hinder a child getting?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Then I do long to see the new ship, and to be on the top of Pauls Steeple when it is new built, but that must not be yet; nor am I so unreasonable but I can stay the time: in the mean time I long to see a play, and above all plays, The Knight of the burning --- what do ye call it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: The Knight of the burning Pestle.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Pestle is it? I thought of another thing, but I would fain see it. They say there is a Grocers boy kills a Giant in it, and another little boy that does a Citizens wife thy daintliest --- but I would fain see their best Actor do me; I would so put him to it, they should find another thing in handling of me I warrant them.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Heyday! so last frost she longed to ride on one of the Dromedaries over the Thames, when great men were pleased to go over it a foot.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well, shall I make a convenient motion for you both?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Quickly sweet sir Hugh, I long for that before you name it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Have you this Spring eaten any Asparagus yet?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Why is that good for a woman that longs to be with Child?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Of all the Plants, herbs, roots, or fruits that grow, it is the most provocative, operative and effective.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Indeed Sir Hugh?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
All your best (especially your modern) Herbalists conclude, that your Asparagus is the only sweet stirrer that the
earth sends forth, beyond your wild Carrots, corn flag, or Gladiall. Your roots of Standergrasse, or of Satyrion boiled in Goats milk are held good; your Clary or Horminum in divers ways good, and Dill (especially boiled in Oil) is also good: but none of these, nor Saffron boiled in wine, your Nuts of Artichokes, Rocket, or seeds of Ash tree (which we call the Kite keys) nor thousand such, though all are good, may stand up for perfection with Asparagus.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Do you say so sir Hugh?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I have it from the opinion of most learned Doctors, rare Physicians, and one that dares call himself so.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: What Doctor is he, a fool on horseback?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Doctor thou lord, you know him well enough.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Yes, we know Doctor thou lord, though he knows none but Lords and Ladies, or their companions. And a fine conceited Doctor he is, and as humorous I warrant ye; and will Thou and Thee the best Lords that dares be acquainted with him: calls Knights, Jack, Will, and Tom familiarly; and great Ladies, Gills, and Sluts too, and they cross him. And for his opinion sake, and your good report sir Hugh, I will have Asparagus every meal all the year long, or I will make all fly for it; and do you look to it Fribble, for it will be for your commodity as well as mine.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: And sure it is a rare commodity when a Knight is become a Broker for to cry it up so.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: And let me have some presently for my next meal, or you cannot imagine how sick I will be.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: But mistake not me, nor the commodity we speak of Mistress. Brittle-ware; where would you have it? here in our own house? fie! the virtue of it is mortified, if it pass the threshold from the ground it grows on. No, you must thither, to the Garden of delight, where you may have it dressed and eaten in the due kind; and there it is so provocative, and so quick in the hot operation, that none dare eat it, but those that carry their coolers with them, presently to delay, or take off the delightful fury it fills them with.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Is there conveniency for that too?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
Yes, yes; the house affords you as convenient Couches to retire to, as the garden has beds for the precious plants to
grow in: that makes the place a palace of pleasure, and daily resorted and filled with Lords and Knights, and their Ladies; Gentlemen and gallants with their Mistresses ---

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: But do not honest men go thither with their wives too?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: None other; some to their own costs, and some at other men's.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Why do we not go then? or what stay we for, can you tell fumbler?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Nay Mistress. Brittle-ware, not so suddenly; towards the evening will be the fittest season of the day: mean while go in and fit yourself for the walk, your husband and I are first for an other business.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Noble Knight I thank you, I hope my next longing shall be to bespeak you for a Godfather.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You shall not long long for that.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: I take your noble word.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: she is gone, and now sir Hugh let me tell you, you have not dealt well with me, to put this fegary into her foolish fancy.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Wilt thou be an Ass now? do not I know how to fetch it out on her again thinkst thou? she shall not go, and yet be contented too.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Aye you tell me so

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Why thou wilt not be jealous of me now, that has lain in thy house these three years, wilt thou? nor think me so foolish to provoke thee with an injury; that knowest me and my ways so well.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I know something by your worship worth the price of a new Pillory.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Why so then; and will I wrong thee Jack thinkst thou, ha? no nor mistrust thee neither: for though thou art a jealous coxcomb over thy wife, and she a touchy thing under thee, yet thou and I Jack have been always confident of each other, and have wrought friendly and closely together, as ever Subtle and his Lungs did; and shared the profit betwixt us, have not we Jack: ha?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I think we have; and that you have some new device, some stratagem in hand now. Uds me, I now remember, is the party come to town?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
Yes; and my Spring has seized him upon the way: and
here I expect him instantly.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: And will he be made a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: That is his ambition Jack; and though you now keep a China shop, and deal in brittle commodities (pots, glasses, Porcelain Dishes, and more trinkets than an Antiquaries study is furnished withal) you must not forget your old trade of Barber Surgeon, it is that must stead us now in our new project.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I warrant you, is he a trim youth?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: We must make him one Jack, it is such a squab as thou never sawest; such a lump, we may make what we will of him.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Then sure we will make money of him.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well said Jack, Spring has writ me here his full description.

div2.stage: Scene 3. Mony-lacks, Springe, Hoydon, Coulter, Brittle-ware.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: 'slid he is come already: now Master. Spring?

sp.speaker: Spri.
sp.p: I come to present a gentleman to you sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How a gentleman? will you abuse me?

sp.speaker: Spri.
sp.p: He finds your defect already; but be bold sir, he desires to be a Gentleman sir; and (though he be but course metal, yet) he has that about him which with your help may quickly make him a clear Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I have four hundred pounds sir; and I brought it up to town on purpose to make myself a clear gentleman of it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: It was well brought up; it appears also that you have had some breeding, though but a Yeoman's son.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: It is true, I have a little learning sir, and a little wit, though last night I met with some upon the way at hammersmith that had more: yet I had enough to perceive I was cheated of a matter of seven pound (almost all the odd money I had about me) at my Card afore thy Card; a pox take the whole pack on them. 'sdaggers if ever man that had but a mind to be a Gentleman was so noddy pooped! O how I could chafe to think on it.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: O but you must not, it becomes not the temper of a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: So you told me; then I thank you friend.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Your small acquaintance sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I have had more acquaintance where I have found less love, and I thank you again good small acquaintance: you told me indeed it became not a gentleman to cry for losing his money; and I told you then, that I should, or would be a gentleman: Whereupon Small acquaintance (because I was resolved to play no more) you advised me to give over; and you told me you would upon our coming to the City, here bring me to a Knight, that was a Gentleman maker, whom I conceive this to be, and here am I, and here is my four hundred pound, which my man has here drawn up to Town, and here I mean to quarter it.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: But I will see what pennyworths you bargain for first, by your Masterships leave.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Drawn and quartered! you have a wit Sir, I find that already.

sp.speaker: Hoy,
sp.p: Yes sir, I have a down right Country wit, and was counted a pretty spark at home. Did you never hear of little Tim of Tanton? But I now mean to have a finical City wit, and a superfinical Court wit too, before I see mine Uncle.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You may sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: And be able to jest and jeer among men of judgment: I have a many small jests, petty Johns, as I call them: But I will have a clubbing wit, and a drinking wit; and be able to hold play with the great Poets I: and with dry jests to maul the malapertest lesser ones (that hold themselves better than the biggest) out of the pit of wit I, before I see mine uncle.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You may have all sir, if you quarter your four hundred pound discreetly: but who is your uncle I pray?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: For that you shall pardon me, till I am a Gentleman: But I assure you he is a great gentleman in the City here; and I neither must nor dare see him, till I am one at least: and I will tell you presently how I mean to quarter my money.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: They will quarter that and you too, if I see not the better to the matter.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Dost thou know the uncle he speaks of?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: No, nor cannot learn who it is for my life.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Some great man sure that is ashamed of his kindred: perhaps some Suburb Justice, that sits on the skirts of the City, and lives by it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well said Jack.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Look you sir, thus had I cast it: Small acquaintance pray do you note it too: I love your advice, that at first sight of me. (which was but last night) could relieve me from Cheaters.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: From some of his own companions to cheat, you more himself.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: The first hundred pound to be for the making of me a gentleman: the second hundred shall be for apparel.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: He speaks half like a gentleman already.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Right, there is half disposed of.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: The third hundred I will spend in pleasure: hark Small acquaintance, we will have wenches.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: What wants he of a gentleman, and go no further, but save the last hundred.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: O Small acquaintance, that must walk too: but all for profit to support my gentility hereafter.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I will be cheated of it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Not in gross, but by retail, to try men's several wits, and so learn to shift for myself in time and need be.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Do you hear this?

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: There is a plot now!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I protest I admire him: I never found like Craft in a Yeoman's son before.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: No words on it I beseech you sir; nor name that foolish word Yeoman's son any more: I came to change my Copy, and write Gentleman: and to go the nighest way to work, my Small acquaintance here tells me, to go by the Heralds is the farthest way about.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well sir, we will take the speediest course for you that may be possible.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: The season of the year serves most aptly too, Both for purging and bleeding: Give your name into this book sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Timothy Hoyden, sir.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Timothy Hoyden.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: But must I bleed sir?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
Yes, you must bleed: your fathers blood must out
He was but a yeoman, was he?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: As rank a Clown, none dispraised, as any in Sommersetshire.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: His foul rank blood of Bacon and Pease porridge must out of you to the last dram.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: You will leave me none in my body then, I shall bleed to death, and you go that way to work.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Fear nothing sir: your blood shall be taken out by degrees, and your veins replenished with pure blood still, as you lose the puddle.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: How must that be done?

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: Aye that I I would hear.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I commend you that you seek reason: it must be done by meats and drinks of costly price; Muscatel caudles, jellies, and cock broths. You shall eat nothing but Shrimp porridge for a fortnight; and now and then a Pheasants egg souped with a Peacocks feather. Aye that must be the diet.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Delicate!

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: This stands to reason indeed.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Then at your going abroad, the first air you take shall be of the Asparagus Garden, and you shall feed plentifully of that.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Of the air do you mean?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: No of the Asparagus. And that with a Concoction of Goats milk, shall set you an end, and your blood as high as any Gentleman's lineally descended from the loins of King Cadwalader.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Excellent, I like all excellently well, but this bleeding. I could never endure the sight of blood.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: That shows the malignant baseness of your fathers blood within you.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I was bewitched I think before I was begot, to have a Clown to my father: yet sir my mother said she was a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Said? What will not Women say?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p:
Nay, small acquaintance, she professed it upon her Deathbed to the Curate and divers others, that she was sister to a Gentleman here in this City; and commanded me in her Will, and upon her blessing, first to make myself a Gentleman of good fashion,
and then to go to the gentleman my uncle.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: What gentleman is that?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I must not, nor I would not tell you that, till I am a gentleman myself: would you have me wrong the will of the dead? Small acquaintance, I will rather die a Clown as I am first.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Be content sir; here is half a labour saved; you shall bleed but of one side: the Fathers side only.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Say you so?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: The Mother vein shall not be pricked.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I thank you sir: I would it were done once.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: But when this is done, and your new blood infused into you, you shall most easily learn the manners and behaviour.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: The Look, the garb, the congee ---

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: And all the Complements of an absolute gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: O brave!

sp.speaker: Mon.
Hoy.
sp.p: By no means sir.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: I begin to believe honestly of the Knight.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Do you note this skin of his here?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Skin, it is a hide sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: It is somewhat thick and foul indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: He must have a bath, and that will be more charge.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: It is pity he should be flayed.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I thank you small acquaintance; pray let me have a bath, what ever it cost me, rather than flea me.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well sir, this house shall be your lodging, and this the Master. of it, an excellent Surgeon, and expert in these affairs, shall be your attendant.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: My man may attend me too, may he not?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Yes, by all means, and see the laying out of your money.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: I like that best: sure they are honest men.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Is that your man? what does he wear a Coulter by his side?

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p:
No sir, my name is Coulter; I myself am a Coulter,
and this is but my Hanger on, as I am my Masters.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Thou mayst make a Country gentleman in time, I see that by thy wit.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: All my friends will be glad on it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Come gentlemen, I will lead you the way.

div2.stage:
Ex.
Scene 4. Touchwood, Walter, Gilbert, Samuel.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: But how can you assure me gentlemen that this is true?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: We saw it not acted sir, nor had reported it, But on those terms of honour you have sworn to; In which you are engaged first to forgive Your son: then never to reveal to friend, Or foe, the knowledge of the fact.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You cannot now but receive Your son into your favour, that did urge him To do some outrage, some villainous shame or mischief Upon that Family as he would shun your curse.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: This is a mischief with a witness to it: He has done it home it seems.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Sir, can a son Do his fathers will too fully?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: You may be pleased to call him.

I would now put on anger, but I fear My inward joy is too great, to be dissembled: Now for a rigid brow that might enable A man to stand competitor for the seat Of austere justice --- Are you come to boast

The bravery of your fact, with a dissembled Show of obedience; as if you had merited Forgiveness and a blessing; when my shame For thy lewd action makes me turn and hide My face --- for fear my laughter be descried.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Pray turn not from him sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I have heard sir of your workmanship; but may A man receive it on your word for truth?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p:
It is too true, unless you please in mercy
To pardon, and preserve me from the rigour Of Justice, and the sharper censure That I shall suffer in all good opinion.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I mean you shall out of the noise on it presently: So --- there is a hundred pieces, get you gone; Provide you for a journey into France, Bear yourself well, and look you come not home A verier Coxcomb than you went abroad: Pray wear no falling bands and cuffs above The price of suits and cloaks, lest you become The better half undone in about at Buffets.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I hope you shall hear well of me.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Pray bless me sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: My blessing be upon thee, Go get thee gone, my tenderness will show Itself too womanish else.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Goodness of nature.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: We will help to set you forward.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Thank ye gentlemen: Be but my son, thou shalt not want a father, Though somebody must seek one: ha, ha, ha --- I would give another hundred Pieces now With all my heart, that I might be untongue tied, And triumph over my adversary now, And dash this business in his angry teeth: Strike Strikers teeth out with his own abuse: Perhaps he knows it already, if he does; I may take notice, and make bold to jeer him: This is his usual walk.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I was to blame To give it so much credit at the first, As to be troubled at it.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: It is the Rascal.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p:
That he, the son of my despite and scorn,
Should gain of Fate a lot to see my Niece, Much less a face to ask her for his wife.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Perhaps he is casting of his will.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Yet the vexation that I was but told so, Lies gnawing in my stomach, that until I vomit it upon that Dunghill wretch; I cannot eat nor sleep to do me good. And I thank Chance he is here.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: He comes, and so have at him.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hum, hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And ha, ha, ha to thee old puppy.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Sirrah, sirrah, how darest thou keep a son that dares but look upon my Niece? there I am with ye sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Sirrah, and sirrah to thy withered jaws, and down that wrinkled throat of thine: how darest thou think a son of mine dares for displeasing me, look but with foul contempt upon thy loathed issue?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Impudent villain, I have heard he has seen her.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Has he but seen her? ha, ha, ha, I fear I shall out with it: I would not be forsworn: I will keep it in if I can.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Yes Malapert Jack, I have heard that he has seen her, but better hadst thou pissed him against the wall, than he presume to love her: and there I am with ye sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Hast thou but heard he has seen her: I tell thee thou old booby thou; if he had seen, felt, heard, and understood her: nay had he got her with child, and then left her, he were my son, and I would cherish him.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Darest thou speak so, thou old Reprobate.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Thou dost not hear me say it is so, though I could wish it were with all my heart, because I think it would break thine.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hugh, hugh, hugh.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I hope I shall keep it within the compass of mine oath; yet there was a touch for him.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: O thou hell bred Rascal thou; hugh, hugh,

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: So, so, up with it, Lungs, Lights, Liver, and all: choke up in a churls name.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hugh, hugh.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I have put him into these fits forty times at least, and not without hope it will throttle him at last --- if you do break a gut, or a rib or two, with straining, a rope will be your only remedy: and so I leave you: by the way you have not heard me say that I know anything by your Niece: But what I know I will keep to myself.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: And hang thyself, I care not what thou knowest, yet thus far take me with ye sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Not a step, unless I were sure I were going to the devil, huh, huh: no sir, you shall not trip me: you shall not fetch it out of me: tush, my son is my son, and keep your niece to yourself, huh, and if she has anything of his you may keep that too huh; and so choke up again with all my heart, and much good do it you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Huh, huh --- hem! so he is gone, the villain is gone in hope that he has killed me, when my comfort is he has recovered me: I was heartsick with a conceit which lay so mingled with my Phlegm that I had perished, if I had not broke it, and made me spit it out; hem, it is gone, and I will home merrily. I would not that he should know the good he has done me For half my estate; nor would I be at peace with him To save it all: His malice works upon me, Past all the drugs and all the Doctors Counsels, That ever I coped with: he has been my vexation These thirty years; nor have I had another Ever since my wife died; if the Rascal knew it, He would be friends, and I were instantly But a dead man, I could not get another To anger me so handsomely.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: You are welcome home sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: And merrily too Fid. Hem light at heart, I met with my Physician, Dog leech, Touchwood; And cleared my stomach, and now I am light at heart. And thou shalt hear on it Fid anon perhaps.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
You are the better able then to hear
And bear what I must tell you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Where is my Niece? How does she, ha?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: As well as a young woman In her case may do sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Ha! how is that?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: It will out, and I as fit to tell it you as another.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Out with it then.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: It is true, I faced you down there was no league Between young Touchwood, and your Niece, in hope To turn her heart from him before the knowledge Of anything that past should be a grief to you: But since I have discovered it is too late; And she can be fit bride for no man else.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: He has not lain with her, has he?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: You speak as just as Gormans lips.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I hope he has not lipped her so: Prithee what canst thou mean?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Sir, if you think The knowledge of a truth of this sad nature May prejudice your health, by drawing a Choleric fit into you, you were best to send for your Physician, your dog leech Touchwood, as you called him, to break your bad of Phlegm, by laughing at you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What dost thou mean now, I have asked thee twice.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I say young Touchwood has touched, and clapped your niece; And (which is worse) with scorn and foul disdain Has left and quite forsaken; and is gone: (They say) sent by his father to travail.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: It was this the villain hammered on today, When he spoke mystically, doubtful words, Reflecting on this mischievous sense: Hell, hell, hell.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: It were good you would forsake the thought of hell sir, And think upon some timely course to save Her credit, and the honour of your house by marriage.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You counsel very well; But were you privy in their loves affair?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Indeed I knew too much on it: think of a course good sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I know no course for her and you but one, Young whore and bawd, and that is instantly To pack you out of doors to seek your living, And there I will be with ye.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Sir that you must not.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: 'sprecious dost thou must me in mine own house?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: In your own house sir, kill us if you please, And take the sin upon you; but out of it You must not dare to thrust us with your shame: Which I will so divulge, as you shall find Your house to be no sanctuary for yourself; And there I will be with you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: This is lusty.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Consider wisely that I know you sir, And can make foul relation of some passages That you will shame to hear.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Remember sir, near thirty years ago, You had a sister, whose great marriage portion Was in your hands: good gentlewoman, she Unfortunately loving a false Squire, Just as your Niece hath now, did get a clap: You know sir what I mean.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You will hold your peace?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
I will speak it though I die for it; better here Than in a worse place: So clapped I say she was, I know not yet by whom you do, and bear An inward grudge against some body to this hour for it. But to my story, good gentlewoman she Was by your most unbrotherly cruel usage Thrust out a doors, as now you threaten us: And miserably big bellied as she was Leaving her most unjustly detained her portion In your false hands, forsook you and the town, To fly the air, where her disgrace was spread: Some jewels and some gold she had concealed: But to what part of the world she took we know not, Nor did you ever care, but wished her out on it,
By any desperate end, after her flight From portion, blood and name; and so perhaps Immediately she was: for which, this judgment Is justly fallen upon you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Yet hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Neither by threats, nor bribes, nor all persuasion, Until you take your Niece into your care: What will the world say when it hears this story Of your own natural sister, and your cruelty, When you shall second it with your Nieces shame?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I never was so mated, so astonished.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Nay, more than this, old Striker, I will impeach You for foul incontinence; and shaking your Old Bullion Trunks over my Truckle bed.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Thou art not desperate! wilt thou shame thyself?

sp.speaker: Fris.
Stri.
sp.p: O I am sick.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Be of good cheer, I will send for your Physician.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Sick, sick at heart; let me be had to bad.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I hope I have laid the heat of his severity, So sometimes great offences pass for none, When severe Judges dare not hear their own.

div2.stage: Act 3. Scene 1. Enter Gardner, and Martha his wife.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p:
Pray let us agree upon it good wife, you are my wife I take it, and I should have the command, yet I entreat,
and am content you see.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: And so would any man I think that has such a help and comings in by his wife as you have: it is not your dirty Asparagus, your Artichokes, your Carps, your Tulips, your Strawberries, can bring you in five hundred pound a year, if my helping hand, and brain too were not in the business?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: Let us agree upon it: and two or three years toil more, while our trade is in request and fashion, will make us purchasers. I had once a hope to have bought this Manor of Marshland for the resemblance it has to the Low Country soil you came from, to have made you a Banke-side Lady. We may in time be somewhat. But what did you take yesterday Mat in all, what had you, ha?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Poor piddling doings; some four and twenty pound.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: What did the rich old Merchant spend upon the poor young gentleman's wife in the yellow bedchamber?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: But eight and twenty shillings, and kept the room almost two hours, I had no more of him.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: And what the Knight with the broken Citizens wife (that goes so Lady like) in the blue bedchamber.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Almost four pound.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: That was pretty well for two.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: But her husband, and a couple of serving-men had a dish of Asparagus, and three bottles of wine, besides the broken meat into one of the Arbours.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: Everything would live Mat: but here will be great Courtiers and Ladies today you say.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Yes they sent last night to bespeak a ten pound dinner, but I half fear their coming will keep out some of our more constant, and more profitable customers.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: It will make them the more eager to come another time then Mat. Have they paid their reckoning in the Parlour?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Yes, but hutchingly, and are now going away.

div2.stage: Scene 2. Gentleman and Gentlewoman to them.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: O here they are going.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I protest Master. Gardner your wife is too dear: Sixteen shillings for a dish of Asparagus, two bottles of wine, and a little Sugar, I wonder how you can reckon it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: That was your reckoning in all sir; we make no account of particulars, but all to Mall, as they do in the Netherlands.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Your Dutch account Mistress. is too high for us to trouble you any more.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: That is as you please sir, a fair day after you:
Who would be troubled with such pinching guests?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: Aye, it is good to misreckon such to be rid of them.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: They are even as welcome as the Knight that comes hither alone always, and walks about the garden here half a day together, to feed upon Ladies looks, as they pass to and fro; the peeping Knight, what do you call him?

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: O Sir Arnold Cautious.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You may call him Cautious, I never saw five shillings of his money yet.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: No, he comes but to feed his eyes, as you say, with leering at good faces, and peeping at pretty insteps.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Sir Hugh-Money-lacke, our gather guest as we call him, sends us no such dull customers: O that good Gentleman! never did any Tavern, Inn, or new Ordinary give tribute to a more deserving gentleman --- O here come gallants.

div2.stage: Scene 3. Enter Gilbert, Wat, and Sam (disguis'd) to them.

sp.p: Three, and never a woman! strange! these are not the Courtiers we look for.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: This is his daily haunt: I warrant thee we find him.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: And it shall take, never fear it Sam.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: By your leave Master. and Mistress. or rather Lord and Lady of the new plantation here.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Nay Prince and Princess of the Province of Asparagus.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: The Island of two Acres here, more profitable than twice two thousand in the Fens, till the drainers have done there.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You are pleasant gentlemen: what is your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Saw you Sir Arnold Cautious here today?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Not yet sir.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Have you a room in your house for us?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Have you any more company to come to you?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yes, we expect some gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Gentlemen did you say?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Yes indeed gentlemen, no gentlewomen I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: In truth sir all the rooms within are gone.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: What they are not gone abroad, are they?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You are always pleasant sir: I mean they are all taken up.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: There are some taken up in them, is it not so?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Still you are pleasant sir: they are indeed bespoken for great Courtiers, and Ladies that are to dine here.

sp.speaker: Gar.
sp.p: If you will bestow yourselves in the garden, and make choice of your Arbour: you shall have the best cheer the house can afford ye, and you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Be it so then; let us walk about gentlemen. Pray send us some wine.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: And a dish of your Asparagus.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You shall have it gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Did you note the wit of the woman?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Aye, because we had no wenches we must have no chamber room, for fear she disappoint some that may bring them.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: She spake of great Courtiers and Ladies that are to come.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Some good stuff perhaps.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Why I assure you, right noble, and right virtuous persons, and of both sexes do frequent the place.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: And I assure you, as ignoble and vicious do pester it too much; and these that respect profit merely have not the wit, and less the virtue to distinguish betwixt the best and the worst, but by their purses.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: It is enough for them to weed their garden, not their guests: O here comes our collation.

div2.stage: Scene 4. Enter two boyes, they cover a Table, two bottles of wine, Dishes of Sugar, and a dish of Sparagus.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And what is the price of this feast boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Playest ill Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: What art thou a Frenchman?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No, I took you for one sir, to bargain for your meat before you eat it, that is not the generous English fashion, you shall know anon sir.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Go get you gone with your wit, and tell your prodigal fools so.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Go, we will call when we want attendance.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Sam you are too sad; let not your disguise alter you with us: Come here is a health to the Hans in Kelder, and the mother of the boy, if it prove so.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I will pledge it.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: We want Sir Hugh Mony-lacke here to discourse the virtues of this precious plant Asparagus, and what wonders it hath wrought in Burgundy, Almaine, Italy, and Languedoc before the herborists had found the skill to plant it here.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: What is he to whom we seek?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Who mine Uncle, Sir Arnold Cautious; he will come, never doubt him; he seldom misses a day to pry and peer upon the beauties that come to walk here.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: It is such a Knightling, I will but give ye his Character, and and he comes I warrant thee: he is an infinite admirer of beauty, and dares not touch a woman: he is aged about fifty, and a bachelor: he defies wedlock, because he thinks there is not a maidenhead in any marriageable beauty to be found among Women.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Yet you say he is an admirer and hunter after the sight of beauty.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: He gets a crick in his neck oft-times with squinting up at windows and Balconies: and as he walks the streets, he peeps on both sides at fair breasts and faces, as he were seeking Birds nests; and follows pretty feet and insteps like a hare tracker.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: This is still mine Uncle.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And when he sees a Coach of Ladies about to alight, he makes a stand, in hope to see a delicate leg slip through a laced smock, which if he chance to discover he drivels.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Well, how your plot may hold to my purpose I cannot see: he is the unlikeliest man to have a wench put upon that you can mention.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I grant the attempt is hard, but the higher will be the achievement: trust my experience Sam: for as in every instrument are all tunes to him that has the skill to find out the stops, so in every man there are all humours to him that can find their faucets, and draw them out to his purpose.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Fear not the plot, as we have cast it, nor the performance in the Comedy, though against mine own Natural Uncle.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Thy unnatural Uncle thou wouldst say; he never did thee good in his life: Act but thine own part, and be not out Sam, and fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: He is somewhat too young to act a roarer: but what lads have we seen pass for soldiers?

div2.stage: Scene 5. Enter three Courtiers and Ladies: Cautious aloofe.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: O here come the great guests.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And these are noble ones indeed; these are Courtiers Clinquant, and no counterfeit stuff upon them: I know them all, every Lady with her own husband too: what a virtuous honest age is this: and see if thine Uncle be not at his old game, bopeepe in the tail of them. He shall follow them no further: Sir Arnold Cautious, Noble Knight you are well encountered.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Good Master Gold wire, do you know these Ladies; or be they Ladies, ha?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Yes, and noble ones, the three Graces of the Court, the Lady Stately, the Lady Handsome, and the Lady peerless, do not you know them?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: No not I.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: How the slave twitters; you look not up at greatness, you mind too much the worldly things that are beneath you: if you had such a Lady under you, (of your own I mean) you would mind her.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: O fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Look no more after them, they are gone: besides they are virtuous, and too too great for you: when will you get a convenient wife of your own, to work out the dry itch of a stale Bachelor?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Go, go, you are a wag, I itch not that way.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Will you go this way with me then, and hear what I will say to you?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: With all my heart, I am free from business.

sp.speaker: Gil.
Caut.
sp.p: In truth Master. Gold-wyer you must pardon me, I may not stay with you: I had almost forgot a most important business.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Even now he had none.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Nay good Sir Arnold Cautious, you know not what I will say.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I say he is an unthrift, a Squanderer, and must not expect supplies from me.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: He does not, shall not, not to the value of a token: pray stay, and hear me sir; it is no ill air to stay in.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Aye withal my heart good Master. Gold-wyer; I like the air well, and your motion hitherto.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Will you be pleased to do your kinsman the favour to further him in a match; I mean an honest lawful marriage match --- but with your countenance, and a good word at most.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: The most unthankful office in the world: pray use some other friend in it: indeed I stay too long.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Hear but who it is that he loves, how likely he is to obtain, what abundant profit the match may bring him, and the desperate undoing danger he falls into if he be not matched, and then do your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p:
Why what new danger is he towards, more than the old
ill company he was wont to keep?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: O sir, he is now in league with a companion more dreadful than them all, a fellow that is in part a Poet, and in part a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Bounce, bounce.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: You have hit upon his name: his name is Bounce, do you know him sir?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Not I, nor desire acquaintance with either of his qualities.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: He is a gentleman sir, that has been upon some unfortunate late services, that have not answered his merit.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: And now he is come home to right himself, by writing his own meritorious acts, is he?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Good in truth, I wish you would see them, to come over them with a jeer or two; I know you are good at it: They are in an Arbour here close by, drinking to their Muses, and glorifying one another for either's excellency in the art most Poetically.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Glorify do you say? I have heard Poets the most envious detractors of one another of all Creatures, next to the very Beggars.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Abroad perhaps and asunder, but together there is no such amity: You never saw them drink; pray see them sir, it may take your Nephew off of his Ningle, who hath infected him with Poetry already: and twenty to one, if he fail in the match, which I was about to mention; he will win him away to the wars too, and then he may be lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Good Master. Gold-wyer go you to your company, I am not a man of reckoning amongst such; besides I seldom drink betwixt meals.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: At his own cost he means.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I commend your temper: you shall not be in the reckoning; but I beseech you let me prevail with you: See, we are upon them: save you Gentlemen: I have brought you a noble friend, your uncle: I know he is welcome to you brother Wat; and you I am sure will make him so Master Bounce: when you shall hear he is an admirer of Poetry and war.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p:
Even a far off I assure ye: I never durst approach near
the fury of either of the fiery qualities.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: It is your modesty, not fear that keeps you at distance I imagine.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Poets may imagine anything: imagination is their wealth, some of them would be but poor else: are you turned Poet Nephew?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: For my private recreation sir.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: What by writing Verses to win some Mistresses to your private recreation: mean you so?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: You dare not sir blaspheme the virtuous use Of sacred Poetry, nor the fame traduce Of Poets, who not alone immortal be, But can give others immortality. Poets that can men into stars translate, And hurl men down under the feet of Fate: It was not Achilles sword, but Homers pen, That made brave Hector die the best of men: And if that powerful Homer likewise would, Hellen had been a hag, and Troy had stood.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Well said Poet, thou tumblest out old ends as well as the best of them.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Poets they are the life and death of things, Queens give them honour, for the greatest Kings Have been their subjects.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Enough, enough; you are the first good Poet that ever I saw wear so good a Countenance: leave it, I would not have a gentleman meddle with Poetry for spoiling of his face: you seldom see a Poet look out at a good Physiognomy.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Think you so sir?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Yes, and that it is a Poetical Policy, where the face is naturally good without spot or blemish, to deface it by drinking, or wenching, to get a name by it.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A death deserving scandal.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Hold, hold.

div2.stage: They scuffle, and Wat throwes Sam, and offers to stab him. Gil. holds his Dagger.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Thy malice, and thy ignorance Have doomed thee.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Gentlemen what mean ye?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: My blood must not endure it.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: You have wronged us all, and me the most.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: The wrong is chiefly mine; yet you add to it By hindering my just vengeance.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I will find a time to right you, or myself.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: My next sight of thee is thy death: I fear you are hurt sir; are you, pray sir tell me?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Let me first admire thy goodness and thy pity: My own true natural Nephew.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Now it works.

sp.speaker: Caut.
