sp.p: I now consider, and will answer thee In a full measure of true gratitude.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: But good sir are you not hurt? if you bleed, I bleed with you

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: O sincere Nephew, good boy I am not hurt, Nor can I think of hurt, my thoughts are bent Upon thy good; you were speaking of a choice sir, My Nephew would be matched to, let me know the party.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Will you sir stand his friend?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Let me but know the party and her friend, And instantly about it.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: He is catched.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: How am I bound to you!

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Nephew I am yet bound to thee, and shall not rest till I am disengaged by doing this office for thee: what is she, let me know?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Sir, as we walk you shall know all: I will pay the reckoning within as we pass.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: But by the way Nephew, I must bind you from Poetry.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: For a Wife you shall sir.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Poetry, though it be of a quite contrary nature, is as pretty a jewel as plain dealing, but they that use it forget the Proverb.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.p:
Come Madams, now if you please after your garden Feast, To exercise your numerous feet and tread A curious knot upon this grassy square;
You shall fresh vigour add unto the spring, And double the increase, sweetness and beauty Of every plant and flower throughout the garden.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: If I thought so my Lord, we would not do Such precious work for nothing; we would be Much better housewives, and compound for shares Of the gardeners profit.

sp.speaker: 2. La.
sp.p: Or at least hedge in Our Asparagus dinner reckoning.

sp.speaker: 2 Cour.
1 Cour.
sp.p: But Madams will ye dance?

sp.speaker: 1 La.
sp.p: Not to improve the garden good my Lord, A little for digestion if you please.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.p: Music, play.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.p: You have done Nobly Ladies, and much honoured This piece of earth here, with your graceful footing.

sp.speaker: 1 La.
sp.p: By your fair imitation, good my Lords.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.p: May the example of our harmless mirth And Civil recreation purge the place Of all foul purposes.

sp.speaker: 1 La.
sp.p: It is an honest wish: But wishes weed no gardens; hither come Some wicked ones they say.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.p: We seek not to abridge their privilege; Nor can their ill hurt us; we are safe.

sp.speaker: 1 La.
sp.p: But let us walk, the time of day calls hence.

sp.speaker: 1 Cour.
sp.p: Agreed.

div2.stage: Scene 7. Money-lacke, Hoyden, Springe, Brittle-ware, Rebecca, Coulter.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You are now welcome to the Asparagus Garden Landlady.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: I have been long a coming for all my longings: but now I hope I shall have my belly full on it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: That you shall, fear not.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Would I were at it once.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well, because she desires to be private, go in with your wife Master. Brittleware, take a room, call for a feast, and satisfy your wife, and bid the Mistress: of the house to provide for us.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: And how do you feel yourself Master. Hoyden after your bleeding, purging, and bathing, the killing of your gross humours by your spare diet, and your new infusion of pure blood, by your quaint feeding on delicate meats and drinks? how do you feel yourself?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Marry I feel that I am hungry, and that my shrimp diet and sippings have almost famished me, and my purse too; 'slid I dare be sworn, as I am almost a gentleman, that every bit and every spoonful that I have swallowed these ten days, has cost me ten shillings at least.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Is it possible that you can consider this, and be almost a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Small acquaintance I do not lie to you: truth is truth, as well in a Gentleman as a beggar, for I am both almost, and perhaps not the first that can write so.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Do you note how his wit rises?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: There is one of my hundred pounds gone that way, all but these twelve pieces.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: You see now what a fine hand you have made of your money, since you got it out of my clutches.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Then there is my apparel, a hundred pound went all in three suits, of which this is the best.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: But what do you think of your wit hundred pound?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Marry I think that was the best laid out: for by it I have got wit enough to know that I was as clearly cozened of it as heart can wish: on my soul and conscience, and as I am almost a gentleman, and a man had come to London for nothing else but to be Cheated, he could not be more roundlier rid of his money.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
Well sir, if you repine at your expenses now, that you want nothing but your Bellyful of Asparagus to finish my work of a gentleman in you; I will, if you please, in lieu of that stuff up your paunch with Bacon and bag pudding and put you
back again as absolute a Clown as ever you came from plough.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: I would he were come to that once.

sp.speaker: Sprin.
sp.p: Take heed how you cross him.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Nay pray sir be not angry, (though to the shame of a Gentleman I say it) my teeth do even water at the name of the sweet Country dish you spoke of (bacon and bag pudding) yet I will forbear it: but you say I shall fill my belly with this new Daintrill that you spake of; these Sparowbills, what do you call them.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You shall have your belly full.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Top full I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: Humh ---

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You shall: but I must tell you, I must have you turn away this grumbling Clown that follows you: he is as dangerous about you, as your fathers blood was within you, to cross and hinder your gentility.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: True, you said you would help me to a boy no bigger than a Monkey.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: And you shall have him, a pretty little knave, you may put him in your pocket.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: Yes wuss, to pick his money out if he had it; shortly it will come to that before it be long.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Coulter you must to the plough again; you are too heavy a clog at the heels of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: Aye with all my heart, and I con you thanks too.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: The Clown, my fathers heir, will be glad of you.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Have you an elder brother?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: You do not hear me say he is my brother; but the clown my father had a former son, by a former wife, that was no gentlewoman as my mother was, and he is a Clown all over, and incurable, even get you to him, like to like will agree well: here is a Crown for you, it will carry you a foot to Tanton; and so get you gone like a Clown as you are.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: It is well you allow me some money yet: we shall have you beg all the way home shortly, when your Cheaters have done with ye.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How villain!

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Why do you not correct him sir?

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: Nay why do not you, he dares not? though he could spare his Clown blood, he dares not venture his Gentleman blood so, nor you yours, it is all too fine I doubt; therefore keep it, and make much on it: I would be loath a jail should stay my journey, or by my Coarsen soul I would see what colour the best on it were before I go. But if I do not your errand to your brother, and tell him how you do flout behind his back, then say Cut is a Cur: And so a fart for a farewell to the proudest of ye; and if you be an angered, take it in your angry teeth.

sp.speaker: Spr., Mon.
sp.p: Ha,ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: What a rude Rascal it is? you are happy that he is gone.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: And so am I, he hindered half my work; seven years time is too little to make a gentleman of one that can suffer such a Clown within seven mile or him.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Would he were beyond Brainford on his way then by this time for me. But you forget the way you were in; you said you would fill my belly; and then fall to practice fine complements and conges to make me a perfect gentleman, and fit to see mine unknown uncle.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: All shall be done.

div2.stage: Scene 8. Enter Brittleware and Rebecca to them.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: See if my Surgeon and his wife have not filled themselves, and come wiping their lips already.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: So shall you presently: now Landlady, are you pleased with your Asparagus?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: With the Asparagus I am; and yet but half pleased neither, as my husband shall very well know.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Well, we will leave you to talk with him about it: come sir let us into the house.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: But half pleased sweetheart?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p:
No indeed John Brittleware; the Asparagus has done its part; but you have not done your part Iohn; and if you were an honest man Iohn, you would make sir Hughes words good of the Asparagus, and be kinder to me: you are not kind to your own wife Iohn in the Asparagus way; you understand me: for aught
I see Pompous are as good meat for such a hoggish thing as thou art.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Well, when we come at home Beck, I know what I know.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: At home, is it come to that? and I know what I know: I know he cannot love his wife enough at home, that will not be kind to her abroad: but the best is I know what my next longing shall be.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: More longings yet! now out of the unsearchable depth of woman's imagination, what may it be?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: It begins to possess me already, still more and more: now it is an absolute longing, and I shall be sick till I have it.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: May I know it forsooth, tell it that you may have it.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: I dare tell it you, but you must never know that I have it.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: If you dare tell it.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Dare; nay be as jealous as you will: thus it is, I do long to steal out of mine own house, unknown to you as other women do, and their husbands never the wiser, hither to this same Asparagus Garden, and meet some friend that will be kind to me.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: How, how!

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: In private; unknown to you, as I told you; it is unpossible I shall ever have a child else, and you so jealous over me as you are?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Art thou a woman and speak this?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Art thou a man, five years married to me; and ask me now if I be a woman?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Art thou so full of the Devil to fly out in this manner?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Why his horns fly not out of me to fright thee, do they?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: O for a hell that has not a woman in it?

div2.stage: Scene 9. Enter a Gentleman and a City Wife.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Look you there Iohn jealousy; there is an example before your eyes, if nothing hang in your sight; there you may see the difference between a sower husband and a sweet natured gentleman! good heart! how kindly he kisses her! and how featly she holds up the neb to him! little heart! when will you be so kind to your own wife Iohn.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Is that his wife think you?

sp.speaker: Reb.
Ser.
sp.p: Indeed my Mistress. will not take this money; there wants two shillings.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Why is my piece too light?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Two light for the reckoning Mistress. it comes to two and twenty shillings, and this is but twenty.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Unreasonable; how can she reckon it,

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I know what you had sir, and we make no bills:

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.p: Well fare the Taverns yet, that though they cozened never so much, would down with it one way or other, and their Jacks, go again; now tell your Mistress. and that will hinder her somewhat.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Not a jot sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Then tell her the Countess of Copt Hall is coming to be her neighbour again, and she may decline her trade very dangerously.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My Mistress. scorns your words sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: You Rogue.

sp.speaker: Wom:
sp.p: Nay sweet Cousin, make no uproar for my reputations sake; here youth there is two shillings more, commend me to your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: She pays the reckoning it seems.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: It seems then he has been as kind to her another way.

div2.stage: Scene 11. Enter Money-lacke, Hoyden, Spriege, Martha.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How is it? I hope you are nor wrangling now, but better pleased than so.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: No, no, sir Hugh, it is not the Asparagus can do it, unless the man were better:

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: But may I now be confident that I am almost a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Without that confidence you are nothing.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: There wants nothing now, but that you learn the rules and rudiments, the principles and instructions for the carriages, conges, and complements, which we will quickly put into you by practice.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: And then the spending the little rest of my money, and I am a clear gentleman, and may see my uncle.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Right, right.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: And I will write it, and crowd it into as many Bonds as I can a purpose to write gentleman; Timothy Hoyden of Tanton --- no, of London, Gentleman: London is a common place for all gentlemen of my rank, is it not?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Excellent, do you not mark how finely he comes on?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: But as I hope to live and die a gentleman Mistress. what she call, your reckoning was devilish dear as daggers three pound for a few Cuckoo pintless, they were no better I think.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Now you fall back again, and derogate from the condition of a gentleman most grossly, to think anything too dear you eat or drink.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Pox on it, I had forgot.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: When he has his rules and principles, which must be his next study, he will remember.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Pray let us about it quickly.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Now we will go; but you forget me Mistress.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: No indeed sir Hugh here is two Pieces for last week and this.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: It is well: Landlord and Landlady will you go?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Would you would long to be at home once.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Sir I do perhaps, and to be here again, and there again; and here, and there and here again; and all at once.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Hey kicksie winsie.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: And I do long to go to Windsor too, to know if the prophecy be as into there, as is reported here.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: How did you hear it goes forsooth?

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: That all old women shall die, and many young wives shall have Cuckolds to their husbands.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I heard forsooth that all young wives should die that were pure maids when they were married.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: And none other?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: So report goes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: You speak very comfortably: It may be a long journey to the worlds end yet.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: It seems you are not proscribed by the prophecy then?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I thank my destiny.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p:
My first work when I am complete gentleman shall be
to get them a Child, and make them friends.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: A most gentlemanly resolution.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: And truly the City is much bound to such well affected gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Is it possible that half this can be true, that a half brother of mine can be made such an ass all over?

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: It is all true, as I am a Coarsen fellow Master. Thomas, every word on it: I scorn to lie in a syllabub I; what luck had I to meet you? I never thought to see you at London.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: 'Sdaggers death, it has as good as seized me out of my wits to think on it: was my fathers blood so quaisome to him, (with a mischief to it) that he must let it out to be a gentleman, because his mother was one (by her own report:) for our own parts we neither know nor care where hence she came, nor whither she is gone, but dead she is) she brought my father a good purse of money, and kept another in store it seems, till I she could keep it no longer, and then bestowed it well and wisely upon Chitty face her son, to make him a gentleman, and told him what great house he came on by her side; for she was a Striker forsooth, and given directions to find an old Uncle of his here in Cuckold shire, one Master. Striker: but first she bade him put his self into fashion, and be sure to bear his self like a Gentleman; and he has taken a wise course to compass it, it seems I warrant he ha made a fool of his four hundred pound by this time.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: Aye, and of his self too, as his Cony catchers have handled him: And you had seen it, you would have be pissed yourself for woe, how they blooded him.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ah.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: And then how they spurged his guts out.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ah.

sp.speaker: Colt.
sp.p: A Bots light on them, it would have made a dog sick to see it how like a scalded pig he looked.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: And then how they did feed with a sort of slip slaps not all worth a mess of milk porridge to make him fine forsooth.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Ah.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: You will see such an altercation in him as never was seen in a brother.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: But I would not seen yet as foul a Clown, as I am, and as fine a gentleman, as he is, I have a trick in my sconce to make a younger brother of me.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: Aye that would be seen now.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I have it, and it is a fine one, I came to London to seek the fool my brother, and have the same directions from our Curate, (to whom my mother told all) that Tim had to find his uncle Strikers house, and I have enquired it out; and this is it, and thou shalt see what I shall do now: who are within.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Who would you speak with.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: By your leave forsooth, I would speak with the Master of the house: I understand his worships name is Master. Striker.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: He is so sir, but he is not in case to buy any cattle at this time.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nor do I come to sell any; my coming is of a dead bodies errand forsooth.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: What strange fellow is this trow?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I pray forsooth, and you be old enough (as it seems you be) to remember when my mother was a maid, did you know a sister of Master. Strikers that was married into Somerset shire?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: What was her name I pray?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Her Coarsen name was Audry, she said, and a Striker she as before she was married; but my father made a Hoyden.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Hoyden.

sp.speaker: Tom.
Fris.
sp.p: Most wonderful, but is she dead?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes faith she is dead, and as sumptuously buried, though I say it, as any yeoman's wife within ten mile of Tanton, any time these ten and twenty year.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Pray what were you to her?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I tell you, my father married her; and I should be her son I think.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Good heaven, how things will come about!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Coulter keep thy countenance Coulter, I will make them believe I am her very natural son, and see what will come on it.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: I will keep my countenance, and set a face on it too and need be.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Your Uncle Striker at this time is very sick sir, but I will acquaint him with your desire: pray walk into the next room the while sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: If he should die now Coulter, and make me his heir?

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: I marry Master. so you might make a better journey on it than the gentleman your brother.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: This to me is the greatest wonder of all, that I am presently possessed of my Mistress. sullen sickness, which has even drawn him to deaths door, and my Mistresses unfortunable condition are nothing to this Country Hoydens relation:
O Master. Touchwood, you are the welcomest Gentleman that ever could come into so heavy a house.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: A stinking one it is I am sure: that nasty carrion thy Master. is in my nose already, I think I were best go no further.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Let not the sadness of this place dismay you.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: But is he dead already, ha?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Not altogether dead sir

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: The worse luck; and how does your Mistress? ha, ha, ha, well well I say nothing.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: She is in bodily health sir, but very sad and much disconsolate, poor Damsel.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Not for her Grandsire, is she: if the worst dog he keeps howl for him, I will worry sheep with mine own teeth, and truff for him, but why is she sad, prithee tell me? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I marvel at your mirth sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I would now give her a new Gown, to tell me the true cause that I might save mine oath, and roar out my rejoicings: it was a devilish trick of the Rascals to bind me by oath never to speak of it, but to those that should tell me of it first. I have such a coil to keep it in now: Prithee tell me, what has the old Traveller that is now bound for the Low Countries, given thy Mistress. in his will, canst tell?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Alas he is offended with her, she has displeased him in somewhat, that is the main cause of his mortal sickness.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: That is my boy, there boy, there, that was a home blow.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: She comes not at him sir, nor dares not see him: do you know anything by her sir?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: No, no, no, not I, not I; 'sbones I bit my tongue too hard.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: If you do sir, would you would speak a good word for her, that he may die in charity with her.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: The jade jeers me, I will stay no longer in the house.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Nay good sir say not so, after so many messages and entreaties, by all the best of the parish, and an exhortation made to you by the Minister himself: did you vouchsafe to come, and will you now come short to see my Master, now the Doctors have given him over, and he is dying?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I confess it was my desire to see that dying that brought me hither: where is he? I will hold my nose, and have at him.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I hope you will be friends with him now sir; for he is even a going.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Friends? I will rather go with him, and fight it out by the way.

div2.stage: Scene 4. Enter Striker brought in a Chaire, Curate.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Look you sir here he is.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What up and in a Chair?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Yes sir; he will not yield by any persuasion to die in his bad.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Then he may live to be hanged yet, for aught I see.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: See sir, your neighbour Touchwood comes to be reconciled to you.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: You are quite besides the book sir Domine, I have no friends in hell to send to by him: no sir, I come to see him die, as he lived a hateful miscreant.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Let me pray and beseech you to speak more charitably, or else not to offend the dying man with your presence.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Do I come to humour him, or you, or myself, think you: you that take upon you, and do rather go about to sooth him up in his sickness, then to fright him out of his pain, rather encourage him to live than rid the world of him, and his abominations.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Best look into yourself Sir: The worlds a stage, on which you both are Actors, and neither to be his own Judge.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: But he has played many vild and beastly parts in it, let him go, I would see his last Exit, and hiss him out of it; hark, the Ravens cry pork for him, and yet he dies not.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: O you are a hardhearted man.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: My heart is not hard enough to break his, I would it were: where is your kind hearted Mistress, fetch her, and try what she can do.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Huh, huh, huh,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: What have you done sir?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: So, so, so, so it works, it works.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Out snarling Hell-hound my curse upon thee, and thy cursed son that has undone my Niece and me: curse upon curse light on ye.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: O fearful.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: How heartily he prays; sure he is near his end.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Pray sir depart, you are too uncharitable.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: My son undone thy Niece: has he not done her thinkst thou? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Huh, huh, huh: Villain thou knowest what he has done; huh, huh.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I know not whether I know or no; tell me, and I will tell thee.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I will tell you then that which you know already, Although you keep it for a joy within you: Your wicked son has by her own confession Done that unto her, that unless he play The honest man's part and marry her, he will Full dearly answer it in Hell.

sp.speaker: Stri:
sp.p: Huh, huh, huh.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Speak English, has he lain with her?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: It is so: She has confessed it to her grandfather, To me, and Master. Pancridge here is made Acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: The Virgin says She is depucelated by your son.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: depucelated, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: It is no laughing matter: therefore send Speedily for your son, before the rumour Make it ridiculous; as yet none knows it, But we a slender few.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Will you direct Your Divine Rhetoric there to him; and win him But to entreat me in this case, and try What I will say to it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Be persuaded sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: In this extremity I do entreat you that they may marry.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I have my ends upon thee; quickly die, And take thine own, thy base submission Has rendered thee more odious, more loathsome To me than all thy former villainies.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Huh, huh huh.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And hark thee ere thou diest, for now thou art going: Before my son shall wed that whore thy Niece, She shall bring all the hands of all the whoremasters In City, Court, and Kingdom, (black Coats, and all) I will spare none) unto a fair Certificate That she is clear of all men but my son.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Huh, huh, huh.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Nay more: That she is clear of him too; and that he Has never topped her in the way we treat of, Before he wed her: for my son shall not ride In his old boots upon his wedding night: So, now die and sink Into thy grave, to rid us of thy stink.

sp.speaker: Cure.
sp.p: I have not known such want of charity.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Unconscionable wretch, thou hast killed my Master.

sp.speaker: Stri.
Touch.
sp.p: The Devil I have, and his Dam it shall.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Ah hem! I am light at heart again.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: O damned old counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Well fare your heart old Master.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Though she prove bastard bellied, I will own her, Cherish, maintain, and keep her from thy son.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: O I could tear that tongue out.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Keep her child too.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Do, and her next, and fill thy house with bastards.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I will hold them more legitimate than thy brood.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: What mean you gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: For thou, thy son, thy house is all a Bastard.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Bear witness, he calls my house a Bastard.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I will make thy house to smoke for it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Bear witness there, he says he will fire my house.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: For neighbourhood and Charity speak lower.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: It is petty treason; I will be with ye there sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And hang thyself old scare Crow.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Will you eat a piece of Gingerbread for your Wind Sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Out Witch.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: O murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I will lay as many actions on thee as thou hast bones in that Swines foot of thine.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: My Nails shall right me: I will teach him to kick a woman.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Hold mistress Friswood.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: O Villain kick a woman!

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Thou laidest this plot to murther me, thou man-killer.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Bloodsucker thou liest.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Help from above, within, or any whence, in the name of sanctity I conjure you. Flectere si nequeo superos, Acheronta movebo.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What is the matter? by your leave which is my sick Uncle? are you scuffling for his money before he be dead.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: We will part you with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Ha you your Tenants, your Clowns here brought in to butcher me?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Slave they are thine, brought in to spoil and rob me; I know them not.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I fear I have conjured up fiends indeed, how infernally they look?

sp.speaker: Tom.
Fris.
sp.p: No, this is my Master.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Say but the word then, and have at them.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Had you your ambuscado for me?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: They are a pair of the Sedan Mules I take it.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: Mules sir, we be no Mules would you should well know.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: We be Coarsen folk as good as yourself, and get you out of the house by mine Uncles leave here.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Your Uncle, O brave.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Or if I baste you not well a fine, and Lambskin your jackets till your bones rattle in your hides, then say cha bewrayed the house I came on.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p:
Well sir, I will go and leave you to your Uncle: rejoice
sir with your kindred: I hope you will have more shortly, if your Niece prove fruitful: Come Master Pancridge, will you go?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: With joy for your recovery, and manners to your privacy, Right Worshipful I leave you to talk with Clown your Nephew.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Tarry, tarry; as sure as a Club, this Clown is sent for out of the Country, to sodder up his cracked Niece in Matrimony, and therefore calls him Uncle; I could spoil the Match, but by my oath I dare not; and therefore Clown take thy course: come let us go Master. Pancridge

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: And why you my Nephew sir?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And why not I your Nephew; has not she told you, and have not I told you as much as the matter is worth, and do ye mean to flee from the bargain?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What new afflictions hourly find me out?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: And for your health, I hope sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Sir, I will have better testimony than your own; It is true I lost a sister; but till you Bring stronger proof she was your mother sir, Your Clownship must not Uncle me; am I with you sir? Kings Crowns have been pretended to byimpostures; And knavery is as rife in Russet Wool, As in the proudest purple; get you gone, There I am with you directly.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Is it come to this now?

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: Your project will not hold Master. Thomas, best seek your brother Tim, he has a certification from the parish, and the Priest too, of all your mothers mind, and you could cozen him on it, and come again, and uncle this weese gentleman, whether he will or no; it would be fine in faith

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Agreed: well sir, for this time I have no more to say to ye, since you be so budge: but he that made you save you

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Farewell sir, I do begin to think there is something in it.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: He made me think he was your sisters son I am sure.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p:
I will not think so, no he was set on By some of my maligners to abuse me;
It had been good to have laid him by the heels: But let him go; call down my Niece out of The melancholy mist she is chambered in,

All makes for her; their vexing me, restores Her to my love again; and reason good; She is mine own natural Niece: and though She has lost the husband, and the name she sought, Yet she appears a Striker; and I will cherish her.
Come you shall grieve no longer, I am friends with ye:

Stand up, stand up I say, and look up too, Off with this mourning veil, and dry those tears: I have considered that right Noble Parents Have pardoned in their Children as great faults; But let it be your warning, not your licence.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: For your security I am content, And would entreat to live in that retirement, Which your fair Justice, and my foul offence Of late confined me to, to weep and sigh My loathed life away.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: No more: you shall No longer live reclused in wilful darkness; Enjoy your former liberty; see, and be seen: And (as you weigh my pardon and my love) Let not your blemish dwell upon your face; Nor any argument of grief, or shame Be legible there, to the most curious eye: But let your cheek be cheerful, and your brow Crowned with as great a confidence, as may Comply with Virgin Modesty: and that Add to your beauty with full strength of Art, Beyond the eye to take a lovers heart.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: In all I will obey you,

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: If I make Choice of a husband for you then, you will take him.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: It will but become my duty.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: A good girl.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
Sir here is the Knight come again, that has been here in the time of your sickness to have seen you, and my Mistress, but
could not: and left a letter for you once: he that looks women through so.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: O Sir Arnold Cautious: did you tell him I was on the mending hand.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Yes I told him you were so, so.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Give me my Gown and Cap though, and set me charily in my sickly chair; his letter is a treaty of a match betwixt his Nephew and my Niece: go fetch him up.
In Niece, and be not seen until I call you: until you hear me call you, do you hear?
Could I but catch this Cautious coxcomb Knight now --- I will put fair for it.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Here is the Knight sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Why reach you not a Chair? I hope sir Arnold You will pardon the necessity of my rudeness: I cannot rise, nor stoop, to you, uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Rather excuse me sir, that press upon you Thus in your weakness: but you understand My business by my letter if you have read it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Yes sir, go forth; but be not far I pray you.
I have heard your Nephew is a wild young man.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: A very bashful boy I assure you; that is the reason That I am won to be a spokesman for him.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: O no dissembling sir; you know he is wild, And suffers under your displeasure for it: uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: A witch could not guess righter: but they say That dying men are Prophets oftentimes. Suppose he has been wild, let me assure you He is now reclaimed, and has my good opinion: And is as like in person and behaviour To gain the maids affection.

sp.speaker: Stri,
sp.p: Speak to the purpose; pray what is his estate?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Aye there is the point indeed: why sir, he has A hundred pound a year; and is withal A hopeful, and a handsome gentleman.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hopeful, and handsome! uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: You sir have wealth enough.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: And she has choice enough Of greater matches: could I get her Into a marriage vein, but she will not look Upon a man not she; but lives retired Here in my house, and is a careful Nurse: She is fitter sir to be an old man's Nurse, Than any young man's bride: uh, uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Is she so grave in youth? I have often sought A sight of her, but never could obtain it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Not without my consent I warrant you; She is nearer to a mother than a maid. I tell you truth sir, and you know deceit Becomes not dying men: uh, uh, uh. For virtue and obedience She is fitter for yourself than for your Nephew: But to the point, a hundred pound a year You say he has, and hopes and handsomeness, Which may acquire, with your assurance of So much for joynture --- Yes, a thousand pound In portion with her: but sir let me tell you, I would rather give six thousand unto one Of mine own choice; which she will not refuse, If I but say this is the man, and take him.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Will not your Niece be seen: I fain would see her.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: At hand: she will not out of my presence sir, Nor ever was by man, not since the clock Of her Virginity struck eleven, not she, Except at door or window, as men pass: And so perhaps your Nephew may have seen her.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: In truth no otherwise; and so he told me. May not I see her sir?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I tell you true; Deceit you know becomes not dying men: uh, uh, uh. And therefore hark you sir, I have a purpose, (That if she take the man whom I will choose) To make her my sole heir; provided that She match before I die: uh, uh, I cannot last.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Pray let me see your Niece.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Friswood --- why Friswood.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Is that her name?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: No sir, I call my maid.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: A maid; I took her for an old woman.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: A maid upon my virtue: and I fear That her frigidity has mortified my Niece: Deceit becomes not dying men you know Friswood I say, I bad her not be far: I dare not strain myself to call her louder.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I will call her for you sir: Fris ---

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hold sir, hold, pray use this whistle for me, I dare not strain myself to wind it I, The Doctors tell me it will spend my spirits,
So, so, enough sir --- Fie, fie upon you: Go call my Niece, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Be of good cheer sir, and take courage man: What you have been a Striker in your days: And may be again, I would not have him die.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Uh --- alas I cannot last --- why comes she not?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: I cannot get her from her work; nor to Believe me that you sent for her, because I told her that a gentleman was with you

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: There was your fault, then I must call myself. Why Anna-bell, ah, ah, ah, An-na-bell.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p:
Take heed, strain not yourself too hard, but send again: The rarest beauty that I ever beheld,
Which with a maidenhead of that growth,
Would be an absolute wonder, her sweet modesty, And meek obedience, justifies that too,

And makes her up a miracle of nature; My former misbelief I do renounce, And at first sight, (which is the birth of love) A faith grows in me, strengthened by the word Of this expiring man, that chastity Has not forsaken beauty.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You shall hear him.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p:
What to propound a husband? honoured sir, Although I rather wish to die a Virgin;
Yet my obedience to your grave behests Shall sway my will: your choice shall be my liking: But let me thus much favour beg, before You make that choice, that you will not destroy The building you have reared; your care and cost Hath built me up by virtuous education, Unto that heighth that I consider heaven; And wax so old in that high contemplation, That to look down on youthful vanities, Were to be at a stand; and to delight in them, Were to fall back again; and to be linked In marriage, to a man whose wild affections Are bent to worldly pleasures a main perdition.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I dare not speak to her for my Nephew now: Nor (though I love her strangely) for myself.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Do you tell me of his Nephew sir? even he The Knight himself, I hold to be too young For a well governed man as the world goes.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I have not the heart to wrong her; she is too good.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Sir, here is a gentleman presses at my heels To speak with you.

div2.stage: Scene 8. Enter Gilbert with his arme in a Scarffe.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Master. Goldwire, what is your haste?

sp.speaker: Gil.
Caut.
sp.p: You first moved me to it.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: It is that repents me: Your base unworthy Nephew has abused me; I do not speak it for a slight hurt he has given me, But for his breach of Faith to another Virgin.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: O me; and would you speak for such a man?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p:
And the false way, the plot he had upon you, To put you on this enterprise, the Quarrel
In which he rescued you, to endear himself to you, Was a mere counterfeit squabble, a very trick Contrived betwixt him and his brother Poet To abuse your goodness: I leave it to your consideration sir: I am in haste; and so I wish you health sir; And you much happiness in a husband Lady.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Has given me here a letter; I want but Place fit to peruse it.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Had he a plot upon me, I will have my plot too; And now woe for myself sir if you please.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Sir, let me tell you, I think well of you, uh, uh, Deceit becomes not dying men you know, She would make even too good a wife for you: For I have heard sir of your disposition, Never to marry without best assurance, First, of Virginity, and then of Chastity, In her that you would choose; and let me tell you, uh, uh, I know not where you can so well be fitted: She is right, uh, uh, if you dare take a weak man's word, Deceit would ill become me, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I take you at your word, and thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Uh, uh, uh, uh --- O lay me in my bad: You need not leave me yet sir.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: No sir, no, It shall be a match, or no match ere I go.

div2.stage:
Exeunt omnes.
They lead Striker forth.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Now sir have you your rules by heart?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Both Rules and Rudiments I have all add unguem.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Repeat your Principles.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p:
Principles to be imprinted in the heart of every new made gentleman: To commend none but himself: to like no man's wit but his own: to slight that which he understands not: to lend money, and never look for it again: to take up upon obligation, and lend out upon affection: to owe much, but pay little: to sell land, but buy none: to pawn, but never to redeem again: to fight for a whore:
to cherish a Bawd, and defy a trades-man.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: And can you observe and keep these rules think you?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I hope I can sir, and have begun pretty well already; you see I have spent and lent all my money; and pawned all my Clothes but these a my back, as I am a clear gentleman; and for the rest of the rudiments, and the several carriages and deportments by garb, by conge, complement, etcetera which are to be attained by practice when I come abroad and amongst them, you shall gain credit by me.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I commend your confidence: now Master. Spring, and Master. Brittleware, play you the Complementasters before him a little, for his further instruction: Imagine them a couple of Courtiers scarcely acquainted fall to; and look that you conge in the new French Bum trick; here Landlord, take his Cloak and hat to appear more generous.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Bum trick!

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Come meet and begin; play but two or three bouts at most at single Rapier complement, and one or two at Back sword and you have done: now observe sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Single Rapier, and Back sword Complement foil.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Noble Master Fine-wit, the single example of court ceremony, if my apprehension deal fairly with me.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Sir, how auspiciously have I fallen upon the knowledge of you by virtue of the same apprehension.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: So, there is one.

div2.stage: Scene 10. Enter Gil. Sam. Wat, aside.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: What is here?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Peace, let us see a little more.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: As I am a Gentleman, a neat bout and fairly come off on both sides.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Sir, I shall ever bless the promptness of my memory, in being so fortunate to collect the fallacious acquaintance of so complete a goodness.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Sweet sir I shall ever bless, etcetera.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p:
O you are pleased out of that noble worth which can convert all things to the form and image of its own perfection
on to make yourself glorious, with that which is miserably impoverished in itself.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Good, there is two.

sp.speaker: Hoy,
sp.p: Miserably impoverished in itself --- O sweet.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Sir, you have such a conquering way in humility, that he shall be sure to come off vanquished that offers to contend with you.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: This is the noblest of all humanity to piece up the defect of your friend with a glory of your own.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: A plain hit that: here were three bouts well played.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Piece up the defect of your friend with a glory of your own: most stately fine, as I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: So much for single Rapier: now for your secret wipe at Back sword.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Aye that I would see, like the hackling of the Millers legs: now for a delicate back blow.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: See you yon fellow I held complement with?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Yes sir, a well spoken gentleman and a lovely.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: The arrantest trifle in a Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: What he is not, is he?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Made only to make physic work: a very lump of laughter.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You have done well: now you sir.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Do you note him yonder that past from you?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: That gallant sir?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: The very scorn at Court; So empty, not one passable part about him.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: A very tilting stock for young practisers to break their jests on.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Good and enough; do you call this good enough, to abuse one another thus?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Yes, this is quacks word Complement: this wipes off the false praise which the first thrust on: you must be seen in both, or you are no true garbist else.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I shall soonest hit on this; for from a whelp I could give scurvy language.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Now break in upon them; say you sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: O course salutation: save you sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How got you hither gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Here we are sir, and have seen part of your practice, your Courtly exercise.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Peace: but how got you in, and a stranger with ye?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: He shall betray nothing.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: We found fair entrance into the house.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: 'Sfoot where is my wife then?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: If your wife be the gentlewoman of the house sir, she is now gone forth in one of the new Hand litters: what call ye it, a Sedan.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: O Sedana.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: He is run mad with his horns.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: He is run with my Hat and Cloak by your leave.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: He will come again, never doubt him.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: You say so small acquaintance; but I could never see anything of mine again, since I came amongst you, if it once got out of my sight: what money have I left trow?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I pray gentlemen which way took she:

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Down towards the Strand I tell you, in a new Litter, with the number one and twenty in the breech on it.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: A Litter of one and twenty in her breech: High time to run.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: You see we have our plot in action too, sir Hugh, and it runs fairly on.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: But what a rogue art thou to put such a slur upon thine own Uncle; first to put him on for thyself, then you with a Counterfeit trick to put him off of that course, to run desperately headlong to break his own neck in a match: what a Rogue art thou to use thine uncle thus?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Nay what a wretch were you, if you should cross your daughter in such a fortune?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Which if I do, cut my windpipe: what the young rascal Touchwood is gone into France they say?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I he is safe enough.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Sir Cautious to be catched I if I do not love my daughter the better for her lucky leg stretching, I am a villain, I am taken with such kind of roguery.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Take heed you have not a cross plot in that itching pate of yours to spoil all now.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Then cut my weasand I say.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And I swear I will, or cut these hands off; I thought good to tell you so, because I know what tricks you have done, and what discoveries you have made for small parcels of ready money.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Hoo pox, I want no money; now look there comes Master. Hoyden, salute these gallants.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: What without a hat or cloak?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: The better for a young beginner.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Sweet sir, I shall ever bless my auspicious stars, that shined me into the fallacious acquaintance of so singular goodness.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Sir you forget yourself.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Most singular sweet sir, most miserably impoverished in itself.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Good sir forbear, make not an Idol of me.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: You piece up the defect of your friend with a glory of your own.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Can you say this gentleman was a Clown within this fortnight?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Within this fortnight I assure you sir, as rank a Clown of one side, as ever held Cow to Bull.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Had it been on both sides, it had been miraculous.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Now note me sir: do you see that fellow I left?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Yes, it is my friend.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: The arrantest coxcomb in a Country

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Made only to make Physic work.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: You do not know him sure.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: A tilting stock for young practisers to break jests on: there is a wipe for you at back sword Complement.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: There is another for you sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: You knock at the wrong door sir, and I pity your ignorance: go to school as I have done, and learn more wit: kick a gentleman.

div2.stage: Scene 11. Enter Tom Hoyden and Coulter.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: Here he is, and here be all the crew on them, and more.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Here? thou mockest he is not here: sure these be all Lords I think.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: How, now; what is he?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: 'slid it is his Clown brother he spake of?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Is it possible? icha made a sweet jaunt after you and have I found a fine fool of thee: where is thy four hundred pound? is that made a fool on too trow: where is the certificate my mother gave thee to find thine uncle? give me that, chill see what I can do with it.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Away Clown I know thee not, canst thou complement?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Complement lies, I can complement dagger out of sheath, an I set on it.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: I hope he will seize you, and make your silken jacket hum: well said Master. Thomas to them, and to them all I will side ye.

sp.speaker: Gil., Wat., Sam.
sp.p: Master. Thomas does he call him?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Yes, Master. Thomas, and what say you to that; and as good a Master. as the best of ye, and you go to that; for by uds shall judge me, I think you are all but a company of Chitterlings; and if you do not give the fool my brother satisfaction for the wrongs you have done him, and me in him, I will canvas it out of the carcasses of some of ye, by uds daggers death will I. Draw Coulter, and amongst them.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Hold sir, hold, you shall have satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: O shall I so, put up again Coulter.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: This is a stout roaring Clown.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Where is the Master. of the house?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: He is run mad after his wife, now he should look to his house.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Cha mich a do to forbear beating of thee yet, my fingers do so itch at thee.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I understand thee not, as I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: But now I think on it Coulter, we will have all again, and by a quieter way; and teach them to lick honey, catch birds with Chaff, or go to plough with dogs.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; who understands the Barbarian trow?

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: Uds vish Master they do nothing but jeer to you all this while now.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Do they jeer, let them jeer and gibe too; I will vetch ones Warrant shall out-jeer them all, and he be above ground.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You shall not need sir; go but in till the Master. of the house comes home, you shall have your desire.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: You say very well sir; say well is good, but do well is better. Let us see what you will do now.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Remember we have warned you sir Hugh, we must leave you.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Nay I chill look to you: sirrah come in my hand.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Now for a trick to rid us of this Clown, Or our trade sinks, and up our house is blown.

div2.stage: Act 5. Scene 1. Enter Trampler and Touchwood.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: It is as I tell you Master. Touchwood; your son has lost a fair fortune in the young gentlewoman, and as I conceive by your wilfulness Sir Arnold Cautious licks his lips at her, I assure you; and a sweet lick it is, six thousand pound in present portion.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: A sweet lick he has indeed if he knew all.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: He does know all sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: If he did, I know what I know; good oath let me not lose thy virtue.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: He knows moreover, that Master. Striker, her grandfather has covenanted to give her two thousand pound more at the birth of his first Child, lawfully begotten on her body.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, but what if her first child prove illegitimate?

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: That is not to be thought sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Yes, and spoken too, if I durst; but good oath let me not lose thy virtue.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: And then he had entered into ten thousand pound bond, to leave her his heir if she survive him.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: But he is well recovered you say.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Very lusty, very lively sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Then hang him, he will never die; I am a feared I must be fain to give him over, I shall never vex him to death: no, no, I shall never do it.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: No sir, I heard himself say, that your vexing him has been his physic, and the best means to keep him alive.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Did he say so? I will tear this match in pieces presently: and see how that will work on him; I will do it, what is an oath to me, in respect of sending him to the Devil, I will do it.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: I would you could sir, and recover her for your son yet.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Um.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Because I love the young gentleman well

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Um.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Though I assure you the writings are all past, signed, sealed, and delivered; but I have them in my hands yet, and can do you a pleasure.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Hum.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: And came purposely to advise you, because I love your son.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Vmh --- what a world of villainy lies in the jobber noule of a Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Think of it sir, and be speedy.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Right learned in the Law, and my sons friend Master. Trampler, Master. Ambodexter Trampler, you are a most notorious knave, and and you shall hear on it on both sides, as you take fees.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Nay, and you be so hot Master Touchwood I am gone.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I know my course; either I will crack the heartstrings of Striker, in crossing this match, with the cracked credit of his Niece, or else I will be friends with him, and that will kill him out right: But my oath still troubles me --- O gentlemen you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Have you heard sir of your son yet?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Not I, he lacks no money yet it seems: Young Travellers make no other use of their fathers.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: But have you heard the news of his young Mistress?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What of sir Cautious being catch, the wise and wary gentleman, your Uncle, that would not believe there could be a marriageable maid, though she were justified by a jury of Midwifes, and therefore purposed to have died a Bachelor: that he should now be catched with a pipped Nut shell, and a Maggot in it.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Sure he was strangely wrought to it.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I you must think There have been knavish heads used in the business.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: But I will cross it and their knaveries, what ever they are.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I hope you will not cross mine uncle in such a fortune though.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What to marry a wench?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: No, so much wealth sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Pray let me use my Christian Liberty, my Conscience pricks me to it, it must be done.
Now what say you sir?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: We might have spared this labour: he was resolved before we came it seems to spoil the marriage.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: We could not be too sure though: we are now sure enough, that our dissuasions will spur him on the faster.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And we are no less sure, that sir Hugh Mony-lacks will set his strength to lift Sir Cautious off of the hooks, in hope of a matter of five Pound, though he forfeit the obligation of his throat by it.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: All the danger is, that Sir Hugh will be with mine Uncle too soon, and prevent the match before he be too deep engaged in it.

sp.speaker: Gil.
Touch.
sp.p: Go fetch them in, and make the warrant: ha, ha, ha: Gentlemen will you hear a complaint my man tells me of certain Clowns that desire my warrant to apprehend for notorious Cheaters, whom do you think?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: I cannot guess.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I know none I hope.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Even Sir Hugh Money-lacks, the mourning Knight, and some of his associates.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: O my life it is the roaring Clown, about the new made Gentleman his brother.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What is it you sir, Master. Strikers Nephew, as I take it, you called his great worships Uncle lately as I take it, and did your best to tore me out of his house.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: 'Sheart Caulter we be fallen into the Bakers ditch.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And do you bring your complaints to me sir, ha?

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: set a good face on it; and fear no colours though.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I am an honest man, and a true man for all that, and I thought you the fittest to make my complaint to because you were the next Justice, to as pestilence a piece of villainy as ever you were Master of in all your life: I come but for justice, and to pay for what I take, and it be afore hand, here it is, whether it be for your Clerk or yourself, who makes or meddles with it, your man has my complaint in writing, pray let me have your warrant.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.p: You shall, but first tell me, how came it that you called that Strike uncle.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: For cause that he is uncle to a fool that I have to my brother, and I thought I might be so bold wee'n, and he was not against it at first, till you were gone, and then he bad me go seek better testimony, and so I went and found my brother Tim, his own sisters son I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: His Sisters son?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Where he was made such a Tim, as never was heard on in Tonton, amongst a many Cheaters: by the mass here are a couple on it.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: These were of the crew.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: How now my Masters: sure fellow thou art mistaken.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No sir, I am not mistaken Aye but I take them Aye, where I find them Aye: And I charge your justiceship with them Aye, till they bring out my brother Aye.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Bring out your brother: why what has your brother done?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Done: nay they have done and undone him amongst them. And I think devoured him quick too For he is lost, and nowhere to be found.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Do you know the meaning of any of this gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: If he were your brother sir, that you found at Sir Hugh Money-lacks lodging, you know we left him in your hands.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: We slept in but by chance, and such a youth we found there, and there we left him in your and their hands, that had the managing of him.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: So you did, but what then did me the rest, but plied me, and my man Coulter here with wine, and sack, and something in it, I dare be swore that laid us a sleep, when we mistrusted nothing but fair play: O speak Coulter, O.

sp.speaker: Coul.
sp.p: And then when were vast asleep, they all gave us the slip, the Knight was gone, and the Squire was gone, and Master. Tim was gone, but he was made away, without all peradventure; for all the apparel that he wore was left behind: and then --- speak Master.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And then the Master. of the house came home, and made a monstrous wonderment for the loss of his wife; he could not find her he said, and so he fair and flatly thrust us out of doors, and is gone a hunting after his wife again: speak Coulter.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Alas poor Britleware.

sp.speaker: Coult.
sp.p: And then we came for your warrant, to find all these men again.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And to take them where we find them, and these were some on them, when time was, and pray look to them.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I know not what to make of this, but sure there is something in it: And for these gentlemen I will see them forthcoming,

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: We thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: And I will undertake Sir Hugh Mony-lacks will be at the Bride house.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And thither will I instantly.

sp.speaker: Gil., Wat.
sp.p: We will wait upon you sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And I chill make bold to wait upon you till I be better satisfied.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: You, shall, come on your way, come gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Well, here is such a knot now to untie, As would turn Oedipus his brain awry.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Be appeased and comforted, good Master. Britleware, trouble not your head in running after your fate; nor break your weighty brains in seeking ways after your wives heels, which are so light by your own report, they cannot crack an egg.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Her credit yet they may and mine.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Besides your wife is your wife where ever she is, abroad as well as at home, yea, lost perhaps as well as found: I am now going to yoke a heifer to a husband, that perhaps will say so shortly: whither away Master. Trampler?

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: To the wedding house: where I think I saw your wife last night Master. Britleware.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Did you sir, did you?

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: I cannot say directly; but I think it was she: does she not call the gentlewoman Aunt that keeps Master. Strikers house?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Yes Mistress Friswood, she is her Aunt sir.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Come go with us and find her.

div2.stage: Enter the Sedan, Hoy. in it, in womans cloaths.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Pray gentleman stay, for I suppose She is here; here is number one and twenty, and this is sure the litter.

sp.speaker: Litter-man.
sp.p: What peep you for; you ought not to do so sir.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: By what Commission ought you to carry my wife in a Close stool under my nose.

sp.speaker: Litter-man.
sp.p: It is a close Chair by your leave: And I pray forbear, you know not who we carry.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: I know the clothes she wears, and I will see the party.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I know that voice, and let me see the man; it is my surgeon.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: A Surgeon! I took you for a China shopkeeper Master Britleware; these by trades are for some by purposes, and I smell knavery.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: And Lawyers commonly are the best upon that sent.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Gentlemen this is a man that lay in my house.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: A gentleman you would say, or my cost was ill bestowed there.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: These are my goods he wears; that was my mothers Gown, and feloniously he wears it.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: It is all I have to show for four hundred pound I laid out in your house; and Sir Hugh put it upon me, and hired these men to carry me --- Whither was it?

sp.speaker: Liter-man.
sp.p: Up to a lodging in Saint. Gileses sir.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Where he promised to finish his work of a gentleman in me, and send me to my Uncle.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: O monstrum horendum; a man in women's clothes.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: It is felony by the Law.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Has sir Hugh gin me the slip to finish his work in private? it shall all out, I am resolved, though I bewray myself in it: pray gentlemen assist me with this party to Master. Justice Strikers, you say my wife is there.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Yes you shall thither.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: And there I will take a course you shall smell knavery enough.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I find I am abused enough of conscience: and shall be carried to mine Uncle now before my time and not as a gentleman, but as a gentlewoman, which grieves me worst of all.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Hinc illæ lachrimæ, the youth is sure abused indeed.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: O.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: Come leave your crying: And you beasts up with your luggage, and along with us; I will fetch such drivers as shall set you on else.

sp.speaker: Litter-man.
sp.p: Let us be paid for our labour, and we will carry him to Bridewell, if you please.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: O, O, that ever I was born in this groaning chair.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: It was well I sent for thee Niece, to help me deck the Bride here, and that the jealous fool thy husband thinks thou art gone astray the while; it will be a means for thee to take thy liberty another night, and pay him home indeed, when he shall not have the power to mistrust thee: it is the common condition of Cuckolds to mistrust so much afore hand, that when they are Duoed indeed, they have not a glimpse of suspicion left.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p:
Their horns hang in their light then; but truly Aunt, for mine own part, I had rather my husband should be jealous still than be cured in that right kind; though I confess the ends of all my longings, and the vexations I have put him to
Were but to run his jealousy out of breath, And make him pant under the frivolous weight He bears; that is, a Cuckold in conceit; Which without doubt he labours with by this time: And when he finds me clear, it will be as well: (I hope) and better than if it were done By the broad way of foul pollution.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
Nay I do not persuade you, take the downright way,
Nothing against your Conscience Niece; I sent For him to ha come and found you here by chance; But he has shut up house, and is run mad About the Town I hear to all your haunts.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: He shall come hither and renounce his jealousy, And then entreat me too before I go.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Yes, that is a wise wives part.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What is the Bride ready?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Yes sir, she is dressed.

sp.speaker: Reb.
Caut.
sp.p: I thank you Mistress. and I will bring her shortly to bestow money with ye in China wares.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: She is herself the purest piece of Purslane --- that ever had liquid sweet meats licked out of it.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: And purer too I hope.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Go call her down.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: She is at her private prayers yet sir, she.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: When she has done, then hasten her away.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Such Brides do seldom make their grooms their prey.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Do you now conclude Sir Arnold you are happy?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: As man can be being so near a wife.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: By your leave gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: He come? I fear a mischief.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: How comes it Father Striker, and son Cautious in election That you huddle up a match here for my child, And I not made acquainted, as unworthy, Until the very intended marriage hour?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Who sent you hither, I sent not for you now sir: And there I am with ye sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: It is true, I covenanted not to come at you, Until you sent for me, unless you found Young Touchwood had the love of Annabell, You have heard he has touched her has he not?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Has he not made her Touchwood too?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Can you say so?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Yes, and struck fire too in her tinder-box.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You will not speak thus.

sp.speaker: Mon.
Stri.
sp.p: Will you undo your daughter?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: My daughter; no you shall not put her upon me now. She is your daughter sir: if I but call her mine, Or suffer her to ask me a bare blessing, You will thrust her out: no, you adopted her In your own name, and made a Striker of her, No more a Monylacks.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: The beggarly Knight is desperate, And should he out with it, my shame were endless: This is the way or none to stop his mouth: It is but a money matter; stay a little

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Go not away sir Arnold, I must speak with ye.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: I am not going sir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Be not a Madman, here, here is forty pieces, I know you use to strike for smaller sums: But take it for your silence, and withal My constant love, and my continual friendship.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Give me your hand on that; enough. Sir Arnold.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: What say you to me sir Hugh?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What does he mean trow?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: You must not have my daughter.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: No sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Unless you mean to take another's leavings.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: O devilish reprobate.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: How mean you that?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Till she has buried first another husband, And he leave her a widow: I am her father, And claim a fathers interest in her choice; And I have promised her to one already, This very day, because I was not privy To your proceedings; and have taken here This fair assumpsit forty pieces sir; You might admire how I should have them otherwise.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Here is an impudent villain.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: For these I give a hundred, if you wed her.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: To show my love unto your daughter sir I will pay it.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Security in hand were good.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Pray lend me sir a hundred Pieces.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I dare not cross this devil, I must fetch them.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: It will never the less be my disparagement.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p:
What, when they know her grandfather disposed her, That has the care of her, and gives her portion?
And then he can have but his money, can he?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: O but the wench, the wench, is such a wench, Scarce two such married in a Diocese, In twice two twelve months, for right and straight ones.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: There said you well; the straight ones I like well: But those that men call right, or good ones, suffer A by Construction.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Amongst the lewd.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: But is here weight and number sir?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Now the fiend stretch thee --- you may take my word.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Here I am with ye sir.

div2.stage: Scene 11. Enter Gilbert, Wat, Touchwood, Tom, Sam.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Though you are fully bent to cross the marriage, Yet let us entreat you not to be too sudden.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.p: Till they come to the word, for better, for worse I will not touch at it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: How now, what mates break in upon us here?

sp.speaker: Touch.
Stri.
sp.p: It is some weighty matter sure then.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: So it is sir, But not to trouble your sconce with too much business At once, pursue your own, we will attend a while.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: In that he has said well: I would the Bride And Priest were come once; I am content they stand For witnesses: what my kind Nephew are you here? I thank you for your plot, you see what it is come to.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: It is not all finished yet sir.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: But it may be All in good time, the Bride is coming now. You and your brother Poet are grown friends I see.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: A friend of Wats he brought for company.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: He was amongst them too at the cheating exercise, and yond is the Knight himself; I know them all I trow.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And you will stand to this, that your lost brother Was Strikers Sister Audreyes son.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p:
I have told you twenty times, and yet because you say you will stand my friend, I will tell you more, she was with child with Tim before my father married her (she brought him in her belly from this
town here (where they get Children without fear or wit) but for her money, and his own credits sake, my father was well apaid to keep it for his own; and nobody knew to the Contrary, not Tim himself to this hour.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Then how camest thou to know it?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: My father told it me upon his deathbed, and charged me on his blessing, never to open my mouth to man, woman, nor child, so I told nobody but folks on it.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Well, hold thy peace, it is an absolute wonder! now to the wedding

div2.stage: Scene 12. Enter Curate, Tramp. Ann. Fris. Reb.

sp.speaker: Cau.
sp.p: How is this? my bride in mourning habit and her head in willow?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: What is the meaning of it?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: I said she was dressed as never Bride was dressed.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: A solemn show, and suiting well the Scene! She seems round bellied, and you mark it too.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: My habit and my dressing suits my fortune.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Pray sir do your office, her conceit We will know afterword.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Hem, hem.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: O, O.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: O me; why Mistress look up, look up I say.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Clap her cheek, rub her nose.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Sprinkle cold water on her face.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Cut her lace, cut her lace, and bow her forward, so, so, so.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: I will lay my life she quickens now with child.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: O.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: What think you is the matter?

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Women how is it with her?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Sir, as with other women in her case.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: How is that I pray you.

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: It will out, it will out, you have been doing something aforehand sir.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Have I?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: It seems so by the story.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Is she so dressed?

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: You may leave laughing, it was your son that did it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: I am undone, my house disgraced for ever.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: He knew it before hand, now I may declare it, Speak on thy Conscience, didst not?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: O my heart.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: O the hangman.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Deceit becomes not dying men you know, Into a whirlpool of confusion Sink thou and all thy family, accursed miser.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: This was a sure way now Sir Cautious, To marry a maid, there is one in the mothers belly.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Uh, uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: You knew not where I could be so well fitted.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: A rot on your dissembling entrails, spit them out, you durst not strain yourself to wind your whistle, your Doctor told you it would spend your spirits, so made me whistle for her

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Cheer up, cheer up. I may be friends with ye now: Here is one has cause, and knows the way to vex ye, To preserve life in you as well as I.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: A hem, a hem, I will outlive you both: This days vexation is enough for a life time.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: And may it last thee to thy lives last hour.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Now let me talk with ye, and come you hither sir.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: I tell you true, your writings are so past, that if you go Not off by composition, you will shake your whole estate.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Come hither Nephew, I will give thee a thousand pound, and take her off me.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I cannot with my reputation now: But I will do my best to work a friend to it.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Prithee do, try thy Poetical soldier.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: That Clown come hither too: I fear I am trapped.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: It is all as I have told you, and without question, The man in question is your sisters son.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Would it might prove so, that I had yet a Nephew, For now my Niece is lost.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Here is one shall find him out: or stretch a neck for it. Sir Hugh you are charged for making of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Now I am in.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.p: And more than so, for making him away.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: What gentleman?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Marry my brother Tim .

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Your patience yet a while: now gentlemen all, Sir Cautious, and the rest, pray hear a story: I have been often urged to yield the cause Of the long quarrel betwixt this man and me: Thirty years growth it has, he never durst Reveal the reason; I being sullen would not.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You will not tell it now?

sp.speaker: Touch.
