sp.p: Indeed I will: He had a sister (peace to her memory) That in my youth I loved, she me so much, That we concluded, we were man and wife; And dreadless of all marriage lets, we did Anticipate the pleasures of the bad. Nay it shall out; briefly, she proved with child: This covetous man then greedy of her portion, (Of which for the most part he was possessed) Forces her with her shame to leave his house. She makes her moan to me, I then (which since I have with tears a thousand times repented) Against my heart stood off, in hope to win Her Dowry from him: when she gentle soul (Whom I must now bewail) when she I say, Not knowing my reserved intent, from him and me, From friends, and all the world, for aught we knew, Suddenly slipped away: after five years. I took another wife, by whom I had The son, that has done that the woman says: But where I left, if this man's tale be true, She had a son, whom I demand of you.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I shall have a kind of an uncle of you anon, And you prove Tims father.

sp.speaker: Tram.
sp.p: The young Gentleman that sir Hugh had in handling, is in the house, and Master Brittleware with him.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Only we kept them back, till our more serious office were ended.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Pray them in, let us see him.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.p: Sir, will it please you first to see a match quickly clapped up? This Gentleman whom I know every way deserving, were your Niece now in her prime of Fortune and of Virtue, desires to have her, and she him as much.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: He shall not have her.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: How can you say so?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: He knows his son I fear.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: My son shall make his fault good, and restore her honour to her if he lives, in meed for your fair sisters wrong and my misdeed, my son shall marry her; provided that he take her in his Conscience unstained by any other man.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: On that condition I will give her all the worldly good I have.

sp.speaker: Sam., Ann.
sp.p: We take you at your word.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: My son!

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I take her not with all faults, but without any least blemish.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: My supposed slain: Thus I cast from me.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: 'Snails a Cushion, how warm her belly has made it.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: And that all was but a plot betwixt him and me, and these gentlemen: This paper may resolve you.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: It is mine own hand by which I instructed her by a dissembled way, to wound her honour.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Which, to preserve my love, again I would do, Hoping that you forgive it in me too.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Now am I cheated both ways.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: The plot is finished: now thanks for your thousand pound sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: You are mine own; welcome into my bosom.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Whoop, who comes here, my brother Tim dressed like Master Mayors wife of Taunton-Deane.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: It is all I could get to scape with out of the cozening house; and all I have to show of four hundred pound; but this certificate and this small jewel which my dying mother gave me; and I had much a do to hide it from the Cheaters, to bring unto mine Uncle; which is he?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Let us see your token Sir.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: This is a jewel that I gave my Awdrey.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: That was my mother.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And that is your father he says.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
Stri.
sp.p: Will you bestow some of it upon me.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Uncle you shall: First I will give you a hit at single Rapier complement: and then a wipe or two with the Back sword Complement and I have done.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Pray begin.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Noble Master. Striker the grave Magistrate (if my apprehension deal fairly with me) whose praises reach to Heaven, for the fair distribution of equal justice: the poor man's Sanctuary, the righter of widows, and the Orphans wrongs.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Enough, enough, you have said very well.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Note you yond justice sits upon the Bench?

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Yes, I do note him.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
Touch.
sp.p: A very Western Soothsayer, thou art mine own.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: His Niece is much suspected.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: Nay there you went too far, this is his Niece, and my daughter now.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: I know no Niece he has, I speak but back sword complement.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: You put me well in mind though, here is one, that ere the Parson and we part, I will make an honest woman.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: And for your part sir Hugh, you shall make satisfaction, and bring in your Confederates.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Here is one that came to complain of me for my Robes here, but I have lost my small acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I will answer for him too, and give you all the satisfaction that I can

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: What you cannot shall be remitted, we have all our faults.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: And have I found thee Beck in so good company?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.p: Aye Jack, be you jealous no more, and I will long no more to vex thee.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Live lovingly and honestly I charge you, or come not at me when I am married.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: This younker I will take care for, And make him a new gentleman by new breeding, Without the Diet, bathing, purge, or bleeding.

sp.speaker: Hoy.
sp.p: Sweet Sir I thank you.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I will home again then and make Tanton ring on it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Our quarrel in this piece of folly ends.

sp.speaker: Touch.
sp.p: He parted us, and he has made us friends.

sp.speaker: Caut.
sp.p: Nephew, and Gentlemen, I am friends with all. You had your plot upon me, I had mine.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Let us in, and end all differences in wine.

At first we made no boast, and still we fear, We have not answered expectation here, Yet give us leave to hope, as hope to live, That you will grace, as well as Justice give. We do not dare your Judgments now: for we Know lockers on more than the Gamesters see; And what ever Poets write, we Act, or say, It is only in your hands to Crown a Play.
